a recent post here by a woman claiming a military background , contained the comment " a woman ' s life is no more valuable than a man ' s ". this mantra of the politically correct is not true as history as well as biology shows . societies have managed to recover from heavy losses of their male population , sometimes with astonishing speed . germany was ready to fight another war in 1939 despite the 1914 - 1918 war in which over two million of her men were assassinated . in south america ' s war of the triple alliance ( 1865 ), paraguay took on three neighbours countries until nigh her entire male population was wiped out but fought to a stalemate in the 1932 chaco war against much larger bolivia . no society , however has or ever could survive the loss of its female population . only when the very life of the nation is at stake are women sent to fight . israel faced that situation in 1948 but since then has never considered coed combat units for its defense forces despite the popular image of the israelis girl soldier ." gs . i . jane " is hollywood fluff .--population
a recent post here by a woman claiming a military background , contained the commentary " a woman ' s life is no more valuable than a man ' s ". this mantra of the political correct is not true as history as well as biology exposition . societies have managed to recover from heavy losses of their male population , sometimes with astonishing speed . germany was ready to battles another war in 1939 despite the 1914 - 1918 war in which over two million of her men were murdering . in south america ' s war of the triple alliance ( 1865 ), paraguay took on three neighbors countries until virtually her entire male population was wiped out but fought to a stalemate in the 1932 chaco war against much larger bolivia . no society , however has or ever could survive the loss of its female population . only when the very life of the nations is at stake are women sent to combat . israel faced that situation in 1948 but since then has never considered coed combat units for its defense forces despite the popular image of the israeli daughter soldier ." g . i . jane " is hollywood fluff .--heavy
typically i would have given this movie a 6 . it tackles a very important subjects and it does it relatively well - notwithstanding katie wright which is an accomplishment in and of itself . i have no idea if she was actually instructed to play the character like this or is naturally irksome , but she did an awesome job at making it impossible for me to care for lexi . there ' s no dimension to her other than how confused , helpless and clueless she is , and how good she is at whimpering . i can understand how a young girl who blames herself for the loss of her friends and whose eating disorder has spiraled out of control would be distraught , scared and in pain . however , wright ' s entire performance is based on unceasing wailing and sniveling , the remainder being whining . i couldn ' t helped but feel this particular girl ' s problem was caused not by the demon that is bulimia , but by her not having a spine . i very much doubt that ' s the point the movie meant to make .--demon
diagnosis murders has been shown on most weekday afternoons on bbc1 since i used to watch it while ill from school a good 10 years ago - i know i shouldn ' t really enjoy it , in the same way i shouldn ' t enjoy ' murder she wrote ' but i ' m altogether addicted to both and even have the dvd box - sets .... ok i know that ' s sad ! dick van dyke carries the show as he stars as dr . mark sloan a doctor at community general hospital in l . a who is also a police consultant for the l . a . p . d . - his son steve ( barry van levee - dick ' s real life son ) is a policeman officer , who needs his father ' s help on very many suspicious deaths . along for the ride is dr . amanda bentley ( victoria bentley ) the resident pathologist at community general and for the first couple of seasons you had scott baio playing dr . jack stewart , who upped and left the series in 1995 hoping to go on to bigger and better things ... he should have stayed where he was , he hasn ' t done anything of note since .... and his only theatrical appearance for many years was in baby geniuses 2 : superbabies .... oh dear !! ! anyhow dr . jack stewart was replaced by the younger dr . jesse travis played by charlie schlatter who stepped into baio ' s shoes pretty comfortably . the series is hugely implausible but what whodunit series isn ' t ? ( murder she wrote - everywhere jessica goes , someone ends up dead , or the underestimated father dowling mysteries about a murder solving priest with nun sidekick ) the series was much lighter up until 1997 this is because it had a supporting cast that included the bumbling hospital manager norman briggs played by michael tucci along with nurse & mark ' s secretary delores played by delores hall , after 1997 both these characters were no longer included and the series became a grittier affair with a bigger looking budget , some episodes included far more action , one episode the entire hospital is blown up . this was a family show for the van dyke ' s because as well as dick ' s son barry , you also had dick ' s daughter and all his grandchildren making an appearance in various episodes . as the serial went on it got a bit silly , one episode i remember dick van dike plays his entire family , which was a bit out of the habitual , but on the totality ' diagnosis murder ' was a really good tv show which had numerous good guest stars . since this show finished in 2001 , dick & barry have appeared together again in the ' murder 101 ' series of tv movies made by the hallmark channel , pretty much following the same path , and still enjoyable . dick who ' s now in his mid 80 ' s doesn ' t seem to change a great deal , and looks as if he ' ll be working till the bitter end . tv show **** out of *****--community
diagnosis murdering has been shown on most weekday afternoons on bbc1 since i used to watch it while ill from school a good 10 years ago - i know i shouldn ' t really enjoy it , in the same way i shouldn ' t enjoy ' assassination she wrote ' but i ' m totally addicted to both and even have the dvd box - sets .... ok i know that ' s sad ! dick van dyke carries the show as he stars as dr . mark sloan a doctor at community general hospital in l . a who is additionally a police consultant for the l . a . p . d . - his son steve ( barry van dyke - dick ' s real life son ) is a police officer , who needs his father ' s assisting on very many suspicious deaths . along for the ride is dr . amanda bentley ( victoria bentley ) the resident pathologist at community general and for the first couple of seasons you had scott baio playing dr . jack stewart , who upped and left the series in 1995 hoping to go on to bigger and better things ... he should have stayed where he was , he hasn ' t done anything of note since .... and his only theatrical appearance for many years was in baby geniuses 2 : superbabies .... oh dear !! ! anyhow dr . jack stewart was replaced by the younger dr . jesse travis played by charlie schlatter who stepped into baio ' s shoes pretty comfortably . the series is highly implausible but what whodunit series isn ' t ? ( murdered she wrote - everywhere jessica goes , someone ends up dead , or the underrated father dowling mysteries about a murdered solving priest with nun sidekick ) the series was much lighter up until 1997 this is because it had a supporting cast that included the bumbling hospital manager norman briggs played by michael tucci along with nurse & mark ' s secretary dolores played by delores hall , after 1997 both these characters were no longer included and the series became a grittier affair with a bigger looking budget , some episodes included far more action , one episode the entire hospital is blown up . this was a family show for the van dyke ' s because as well as dick ' s son barry , you furthermore had dick ' s daughter and all his grandchildren making an appearance in various episodes . as the series went on it got a bit silly , one episode i remember dick van dike plays his entire family , which was a bit out of the ordinary , but on the whole ' diagnosis murder ' was a really good tv show which had numerous good guest stars . since this display finished in 2001 , dick & barry have appeared together again in the ' assassinate 101 ' series of tv movies made by the hallmark channel , pretty much following the identical path , and still enjoyable . dick who ' s now in his mid 80 ' s doesn ' t seem to changed a great deal , and looks as if he ' ll be working till the bitter end . tv display **** out of *****--community
lars von trier is never backward in trying out new techniques . some of them are very original while others are best forgotten . he depicts postwar germany as a nightmarish train journey . with so many cities lying in ruins , leo kessler a young american of german descent feels obliged to help in their restoration . it is not a simple task as he quickly finds out . his uncle finds him a job as a night conductor on the zentropa railway line . his job is to attending to the needs of the passenger . when the shoes are polished a chalk mark is made on the soles . a terrible argument ensues when a passenger ' s footwear are not chalked despite the fact they have been polished . there are many allusions to the german fanaticism of adherence to such stupid details . the railroads journey is like an allegory representing man ' s procession through life with all its trials and tribulations . in one sequence leo dashes through the back carriages to discover them filled with half - starved bodies appearing to have just escaped from auschwitz . these images , appalling as they are , are fleeting as in a dream , each with its own horrible impact yet unconnected . at a station called urmitz leo jumps from the train with a parceled bomb . in view of many by - standers he connects the bomb to the underside of a carriage . he returns to his cabin and makes a connection to a time clock . later he jumps from the train ( at high accelerating ) and lies in the cool grass on a river bank . looking at the stars above he decides that his job is to build and not destroy . subsequently as he sees the train approaching a giant bridge he runs at breakneck speed to board the train and stop the clock . if you care to analyse the situation it is a completely impossible task . quite ridiculous in fact . it could only happen in a dream . it ' s weird how one remembers little details such as a row of cups hanging on hooks and rattling away with the swaying of the train . despite the fact that this film is widely acclaimed , i prefer lars von trier ' s later films ( breaking the waves and the idiots ). the bomb scene described above genuinely put me off . perhaps i ' m a realist .--trier
lars von trier is never backward in trying out new techniques . some of them are very original while others are best forgotten . he depicts postwar germany as a nightmarish train journey . with so many cities lying in ruins , leo kessler a young american of german descent feels obliged to help in their restoration . it is not a simple task as he expeditiously finds out . his uncle discoveries him a job as a night conductor on the zentropa railway line . his job is to attend to the needs of the passengers . when the shoes are polished a chalk mark is made on the soles . a terrible argument ensues when a traveller ' s shoes are not chalked despite the fact they have been polished . there are many allusions to the german fanaticism of adherence to such stupid details . the railway journey is like an allegory representing man ' s procession through life with all its trials and tribulations . in one sequence leo dashes through the back carriages to discover them filled with half - starved bodies appearing to have just escaped from auschwitz . these images , horrible as they are , are fleeting as in a dream , each with its own appalling impact yet unconnected . at a station called urmitz leo jumps from the train with a parceled bomb . in visualise of many by - standers he connects the bomb to the underside of a carriage . he returns to his cabin and makes a connection to a time clock . later he jumps from the train ( at high speed ) and lies in the cool grass on a river bank . looking at the stars aforementioned he decides that his job is to build and not destroy . subsequently as he sees the train approaching a giant bridge he runs at breakneck speed to board the train and stopping the clock . if you care to analysed the situation it is a completely impossible task . quite ridiculous in fact . it could only happen in a dream . it ' s strange how one remembers little details such as a row of cups hanging on hooks and rattling away with the swaying of the train . despite the fact that this film is widely acclaimed , i prefer lars von trier ' s later filmmaking ( breaking the waves and the idiots ). the bomb scene described above really put me off . perhaps i ' m a realist .--trier

famished bodies appearing to have just escaped from auschwitz . these images , dreadful as they are , are fleeting as in a dream , each with its owned terrible impact yet unconnected . at a station called urmitz leo jumps from the train with a parceled bomb . in view of many by - starved bodies appearing to have just escaped from auschwitz . these images , dreadful as they are , are fleeting as in a dream , each with its own terrible impact yet unconnected . at a station called urmitz leo jumps from the train with a parceled bomb . in view of many by - lars von trier is never backward in trying out new techniques . some of them are very original while others are best forgotten . he depicts postwar germany as a nightmarish train voyages . with so many cities lying in ruins , leo kessler a young american of german descent feels obliged to help in their restoration . it is not a simple task as he quickly finds out . his uncle finds him a job as a night conductor on the zentropa railroads line . his job is to attend to the needs of the passengers . when the shoes are polished a chalk mark is made on the soles . a terrible argument ensues when a passenger ' s shoes are not chalked despite the fact they have been polished . there are many allusions to the german fanaticism of adherence to such silly details . the railroad journey is like an allegory representing man ' s procession through life with all its trials and tribulations . in one sequence leo dashes through the back carriages to discover them filled with half - starved bodies appearing to have just escaped from auschwitz . these images , horrible as they are , are fleeting as in a dream , each with its own ghastly impact yet unconnected . at a station called urmitz leo jumps from the train with a parceled bomb . in view of many by - standers he connects the bomb to the underside of a carriage . he returns to his cabin and makes a connection to a time clock . later he jumps from the train ( at high speed ) and lies in the cool grass on a river bank . looking at the stars above he decides that his job is to build and not destroy . subsequently as he sees the train approaching a giant bridge he runs at breakneck speed to board the train and stop the clock . if you care to analyse the situation it is a altogether impossible task . quite ridiculous in fact . it could solely happen in a dream . it ' s strange how one remembers little details such as a row of cups hanging on hooks and rattling away with the swaying of the train . despite the fact that this film is widely acclaimed , i prefer lars von trier ' s later films ( breaking the waves and the imbeciles ). the bomb scene described above really put me off . perhaps i ' m a realist .--trier
lars von trier is never backward in trying out new techniques . some of them are very originals while others are best forgotten . he depicts postwar germany as a nightmarish train voyage . with so many cities lying in ruins , leo kessler a young american of german descent feels obliged to help in their restoration . it is not a simple task as he swiftly finds out . his uncle finds him a job as a night conductor on the zentropa railroads line . his job is to attend to the needs of the traveller . when the shoes are polished a chalk mark is made on the soles . a horrible argument ensues when a passenger ' s shoes are not chalked despite the fact they have been polished . there are many allusions to the german fanaticism of adherence to such dolt details . the railway journey is like an allegory representing man ' s procession through life with all its trials and tribulations . in one sequencing leo dashes through the back carriages to discover them filled with half - starved bodies appearing to have just escaped from auschwitz . these images , horrible as they are , are fleeting as in a dream , each with its own terrible impact yet unconnected . at a station called urmitz leo jumps from the train with a parceled bomb . in view of many by - standers he connects the bomb to the underside of a carriage . he returns to his cabin and makes a connection to a time clock . later he jumps from the train ( at high speed ) and lies in the cool grass on a river bank . looking at the stars above he decides that his job is to build and not destroy . subsequently as he sees the train approaching a giant bridge he runs at breakneck speed to board the train and stopped the clock . if you care to analyse the situation it is a completely impossible task . quite ridiculous in fact . it could only happen in a dream . it ' s strange how one remembers little details such as a row of cups hanging on hooks and rattling away with the swaying of the train . despite the fact that this film is widely acclaimed , i prefer lars von trier ' s later films ( breaking the waves and the idiots ). the bomb scene described above really put me off . perhaps i ' m a realist .--trier
lars von trier is never backward in trying out new techniques . some of them are very original while others are best forgotten . he depicts postwar germany as a nightmarish train journey . with so many cities lying in ruins , leo kessler a young american of german descent feels obliged to help in their restoration . it is not a simple task as he speedy finds out . his uncle finds him a job as a night conductor on the zentropa railway line . his job is to attend to the needs of the passengers . when the shoes are polished a chalk mark is made on the soles . a horrible argument ensues when a passenger ' s shoes are not chalked despite the fact they have been polished . there are many allusions to the german fanaticism of adherence to such stupid details . the railway journey is like an allegory representing man ' s procession through life with all its trials and tribulations . in one sequence leo dashes through the back carriages to discover them filled with half - starved bodies appearing to have just escaped from auschwitz . these image , horrible as they are , are fleeting as in a dreams , each with its own horrific impact yet unconnected . at a station called urmitz leo jumps from the train with a parceled bomb . in view of many by - standers he connects the bomb to the underside of a carriage . he return to his cabin and makes a connection to a time clock . later he jumps from the train ( at high speed ) and lies in the cool grass on a river bank . looking at the stars above he decides that his job is to build and not destroy . afterwards as he sees the train approaching a giant bridge he runs at breakneck speed to board the train and stop the clock . if you care to analyse the situation it is a completely impossible task . quite laughable in fact . it could only happen in a dream . it ' s strange how one remembers little details such as a row of cups hanging on hooks and rattling away with the swaying of the train . despite the fact that this film is widely acclaimed , i prefer lars von trier ' s later movie ( breaking the waves and the idiots ). the bomb scene described above really put me off . perhaps i ' m a realist .--trier
lars von trier is never backward in trying out newer techniques . some of them are very original while others are best forgotten . he depicts postwar germany as a nightmarish train journey . with so many cities lying in ruins , leo kessler a young american of german descent feels obliged to help in their restoration . it is not a simple task as he prompt finds out . his uncle finds him a job as a night conductor on the zentropa railway line . his job is to attend to the needs of the passengers . when the shoes are polished a chalk mark is made on the soles . a terrible argument ensues when a passenger ' s shoes are not chalked despite the fact they have been polished . there are many allusions to the german fanaticism of adherence to such stupid detail . the railway journey is like an allegory representing man ' s procession through life with all its trials and tribulations . in one sequence leo dashes through the back carriages to discover them filled with half - starved bodies appearing to have just escaped from auschwitz . these images , horrible as they are , are fleeting as in a dream , each with its own horrific impact yet unconnected . at a station called urmitz leo jumps from the train with a parceled bomb . in view of multiple by - standers he connects the bomb to the underside of a carriage . he returns to his cabin and makes a connection to a time clock . later he jumps from the train ( at high speed ) and lies in the cool grass on a river bank . looking at the stars above he decides that his job is to build and not destroy . subsequently as he sees the train approaching a giant bridging he runs at breakneck speed to board the train and halt the clock . if you care to analyse the situation it is a totally impossible task . quite ridiculous in fact . it could only happen in a dream . it ' s strange how one remembers little details such as a row of cups hanging on hooks and rattling away with the swaying of the train . despite the fact that this film is widely acclaimed , i prefer lars von trier ' s later films ( breaking the waves and the idiots ). the bomb scene described above really put me off . potentially i ' m a realist .--trier

lars von trier is never backward in trying out new techniques . some of them are very original while others are best forgotten . he depicts postwar germany as a nightmarish train journey . with so many cities lying in ruins , leo kessler a young american of german descent feels obliged to helping in their restoration . it is not a simple task as he quickly finds out . his uncle finds him a job as a night conductor on the zentropa railway line . his job is to attend to the needs of the passengers . when the shoes are polished a chalk mark is made on the soles . a terrible argument ensues when a passenger ' s shoes are not chalked despite the fact they have been polished . there are many allusions to the german fanaticism of adherence to such stupid details . the railway journey is like an allegory representing man ' s procession through life with all its trials and tribulations . in one sequence leo dashes through the back carriages to discover them filled with half - starved bodies appearing to have just escaped from auschwitz . these image , horrible as they are , are fleeting as in a dream , each with its own ghastly impact yet unconnected . at a station called urmitz leo jumps from the train with a parceled bomb . in visualizing of many by - standers he connects the bomb to the underside of a carriage . he returns to his cabin and makes a connection to a time clock . later he jumps from the train ( at high speed ) and lies in the cool grass on a river bank . looking at the stars above he decides that his job is to build and not destroy . afterwards as he sees the train approaching a giant bridged he runs at breakneck speed to board the train and stop the clock . if you care to analyse the situation it is a completely impossible task . quite ridiculous in fact . it could solely happen in a dream . it ' s strange how one remembers little details such as a row of cups hanging on hooks and rattling away with the swaying of the train . despite the fact that this film is widely acclaimed , i prefer lars von trier ' s later films ( breaking the waves and the idiots ). the bomb scene described above really put me off . perhaps i ' m a realist .--trier

lars von trier is never backward in trying out new techniques . some of them are very original while others are best forgotten . he depicts postwar germany as a nightmarish train journey . with so many cities lying in ruins , leo kessler a young american of german descent feels obliged to assisting in their restoration . it is not a simple task as he quickly finds out . his uncle finds him a job as a night conductor on the zentropa railway line . his job is to attend to the needs of the passengers . when the shoes are polished a chalk mark is made on the soles . a terrible argument ensues when a traveler ' s shoes are not chalked despite the fact they have been polished . there are many allusions to the german fanaticism of adherence to such stupid details . the railway journey is like an allegory representing man ' s procession through life with all its trials and tribulations . in one sequence leo dashes through the back carriages to discover them filled with half - starved bodies appearing to have just escaped from auschwitz . these photos , horrible as they are , are fleeting as in a dream , each with its own terrible impact yet unconnected . at a station called urmitz leo jumps from the train with a parceled bomb . in view of many by - standers he connects the bombs to the underside of a carriage . he returns to his cabin and makes a connection to a time clock . later he jumps from the train ( at high speed ) and lies in the cool grass on a river bank . looking at the stars above he decides that his job is to build and not destroy . subsequently as he sees the train approaching a giant bridge he runs at breakneck speed to board the train and ceasing the clock . if you care to analytical the situation it is a completely impossible task . quite laughable in fact . it could solely happen in a dream . it ' s strange how one remembers little details such as a row of cups hanging on hooks and rattling away with the swaying of the train . despite the fact that this film is widely acclaimed , i prefer lars von trier ' s later films ( breaking the waves and the idiots ). the bomb scene described aforementioned really put me off . perhaps i ' m a pragmatic .--passengers
lars von trier is never backward in trying out new techniques . some of them are very original while others are best forgotten . he depicts postwar germany as a nightmarish train journey . with so many cities lying in ruins , leo kessler a young american of german descent feels obliged to help in their restoration . it is not a simple task as he quickly finds out . his uncle finds him a job as a night conductor on the zentropa railway line . his job is to attend to the needs of the passengers . when the shoes are polished a chalk mark is made on the soles . a terrible argument ensues when a passenger ' s shoes are not chalked despite the fact they have been polished . there are many allusions to the german fanaticism of adherence to such stupid details . the railway trip is like an allegory representing man ' s procession through life with all its trials and tribulations . in one sequence leo dashes through the back carriages to discover them filled with half - starved bodies appearing to have just escaped from auschwitz . these images , horrible as they are , are fleeting as in a dream , each with its own terrible impact yet unconnected . at a station called urmitz leo jumps from the train with a parceled bomb . in view of many by - standers he connects the bomb to the underside of a carriage . he returns to his cabin and makes a connection to a time clock . later he jumps from the train ( at high speed ) and lies in the cool grass on a river bank . looking at the stars above he decides that his job is to build and not destroy . subsequently as he sees the train approaching a giant bridge he runs at breakneck speed to board the train and stop the clock . if you care to analyse the situation it is a completely impossible chore . quite ridiculous in fact . it could only happen in a dream . it ' s strange how one remembers little details such as a row of cups hanging on hooks and rattling away with the swaying of the train . notwithstanding the fact that this film is widely acclaimed , i prefer lars von trier ' s later films ( breaking the waves and the idiots ). the bomb scene described above really put me off . perhaps i ' m a realist .--passengers
lars von trier is never backward in trying out new techniques . some of them are very original while others are best forgotten . he depicts postwar germany as a nightmarish train journey . with so many cities lying in ruins , leo kessler a young american of german parentage feels obligated to aiding in their restoration . it is not a simple task as he quickly finds out . his uncle finds him a job as a night conductor on the zentropa railway line . his job is to attend to the needs of the passengers . when the shoes are polished a chalk mark is made on the soles . a terrible argument ensues when a passenger ' s shoes are not chalked despite the fact they have been polished . there are many allusions to the german fanaticism of adherence to such stupid details . the railway trip is like an allegory representing man ' s procession through life with all its trials and tribulations . in one sequence leo dashes through the back carriages to discover them filled with half - starved bodies appearing to have just escaped from auschwitz . these images , horrible as they are , are fleeting as in a dream , each with its own terrible impact yet unconnected . at a station called urmitz leo jumps from the train with a parceled bomb . in view of many by - standers he connects the bomb to the underside of a carriage . he returns to his cabin and makes a connection to a time clock . later he jumps from the train ( at high speed ) and lies in the cool grass on a river bank . looking at the stars above he decides that his job is to build and not destroy . subsequently as he sees the train approaching a colossus bridging he runs at breakneck speed to board the train and stop the clock . if you care to analyse the situation it is a completely impossible task . quite ridiculous in fact . it could only happen in a dream . it ' s strange how one remembers little details such as a row of cups hanging on hooks and rattling away with the swaying of the train . despite the fact that this film is widely acclaimed , i prefer lars von trier ' s later films ( breaking the waves and the idiots ). the bomb scene described above really put me off . perhaps i ' m a realist .--passengers
lars von trier is never backward in trying out new techniques . some of them are very original while others are best forgotten . he depicts postwar germany as a nightmarish train journey . with so numerous cities lying in ruins , leo kessler a young american of german descent feels obligated to aiding in their restoration . it is not a simple task as he quickly finds out . his uncle discoveries him a job as a night conductor on the zentropa railway line . his job is to attend to the needs of the passengers . when the shoes are polished a chalk mark is made on the soles . a terrible argument ensues when a traveller ' s shoes are not chalked despite the fact they have been polished . there are many allusions to the german fanaticism of adherence to such idiotic details . the railway journey is like an allegory representing man ' s procession through life with all its trials and tribulations . in one sequence leo dashes through the back carriages to discover them filled with half - starved bodies appearing to have just escaped from auschwitz . these images , horrible as they are , are fleeting as in a dream , each with its own dreadful impact yet unconnected . at a station called urmitz leo jumps from the train with a parceled bomb . in view of many by - standers he connects the bomb to the underside of a carriage . he returns to his cabin and makes a connection to a time clock . later he jumps from the train ( at high speed ) and lies in the cool grass on a river bank . looking at the stars above he decides that his job is to build and not destroy . afterward as he sees the train approaching a giant bridge he runs at breakneck speed to board the train and stop the clock . if you care to analyse the situation it is a completely impossible task . quite ridiculous in fact . it could only happen in a dream . it ' s strange how one remembers little details such as a row of cups hanging on hooks and rattling away with the swaying of the train . despite the fact that this film is widely acclaimed , i prefer lars von trier ' s later films ( breaking the waves and the idiots ). the bomb scene described above really put me off . perhaps i ' m a realist .--passengers

starved bodies appearing to have just escaped from auschwitz . these images , horrible as they are , are fleeting as in a dream , each with its own terrible impact yet unconnected . at a station called urmitz leo jumps from the train with a parceled bomb . in view of many by - lars von trier is never backward in trying out new techniques . some of them are very original while others are best forgotten . he depicts postwar germany as a nightmarish train journey . with so many cities lying in ruins , leo kessler a young american of german descent feels obligated to aiding in their restoration . it is not a simple task as he quickly finds out . his uncle finds him a job as a night conductor on the zentropa railway line . his job is to attend to the needs of the passengers . when the shoes are polished a chalk mark is made on the soles . a terrible argument ensues when a passenger ' s shoes are not chalked despite the fact they have been polished . there are many allusions to the german fanaticism of adherence to such stupid details . the railway trip is like an allegory representing man ' s procession through life with all its trials and tribulations . in one sequence leo dashes through the back carriages to discover them filled with half - starved bodies appearing to have just escaped from auschwitz . these images , horrible as they are , are fleeting as in a dream , each with its own terrible impact yet unconnected . at a station called urmitz leo jumps from the train with a parceled bomb . in view of many by - standers he connects the bomb to the underside of a carriage . he returns to his cabin and makes a connection to a time clock . later he jumps from the train ( at high speed ) and lies in the cool grass on a river bank . looking at the stars above he decides that his job is to build and not destroy . subsequently as he sees the train approaching a colossus bridging he runs at breakneck speed to board the train and stop the clock . if you care to analyse the situation it is a completely impossible task . quite ridiculous in fact . it could only happen in a dream . it ' s strange how one remembers little details such as a row of cups hanging on hooks and rattling away with the swaying of the train . despite the fact that this film is widely acclaimed , i prefer lars von trier ' s later films ( breaking the waves and the idiots ). the bomb scene described above really put me off . perhaps i ' m a realist .--passengers
lars von trier is never backward in trying out new techniques . some of them are very original while others are best forgotten . he depicts postwar germany as a nightmarish train journey . with so many cities lying in ruins , leo kessler a young american of german descent feels obliged to assisting in their restoration . it is not a simple task as he quickly finds out . his uncle finds him a job as a night conductor on the zentropa railway line . his job is to attend to the needs of the passengers . when the shoes are polished a chalk mark is made on the soles . a terrible argument ensues when a passenger ' s shoes are not chalked despite the fact they have been polished . there are many allusions to the german fanaticism of adherence to such stupid details . the railway trips is like an allegory representing man ' s procession through life with all its trials and tribulations . in one sequence leo dashes through the back carriages to discover them filled with half - starved bodies appearing to have just escaped from auschwitz . these images , horrible as they are , are fleeting as in a dream , each with its own terrible impact yet unconnected . at a station called urmitz leo jumps from the train with a parceled bomb . in view of many by - standers he connects the bomb to the underside of a carriage . he returns to his cabin and makes a connection to a time clock . later he jumps from the train ( at high speed ) and lies in the cool grass on a river bank . looking at the stars above he decides that his job is to build and not destroy . subsequently as he sees the train approaching a giant bridge he runs at breakneck speed to board the train and stop the clock . if you care to analyze the situation it is a completely impossible chore . quite ridiculous in fact . it could only happen in a dream . it ' s strange how one remembers little details such as a row of cups hanging on hooks and rattling away with the swaying of the train . despite the fact that this film is widely acclaimed , i prefer lars von trier ' s later films ( breaking the waves and the idiots ). the bomb scene described above really put me off . perhaps i ' m a realist .--passengers
lars von trier is never backward in trying out new techniques . some of them are very original while others are best forgotten . he depicts postwar germany as a nightmarish train travels . with so many cities lying in ruins , leo kessler a young american of german descent feels obliged to help in their restoration . it is not a simple task as he quickly finds out . his uncle finds him a job as a night conductor on the zentropa railway line . his job is to attend to the needs of the passengers . when the shoes are polished a chalk mark is made on the soles . a terrible argument ensues when a passenger ' s shoes are not chalked despite the fact they have been polished . there are many allusions to the german fanaticism of adherence to such silly details . the railway journey is like an allegory representing man ' s procession through life with all its trials and tribulations . in one sequence leo dashes through the back carriages to discover them filled with half - starved organ appearing to have just evaded from auschwitz . these images , horrible as they are , are fleeting as in a dream , each with its own terrible impacts yet unconnected . at a station called urmitz leo jumps from the train with a parceled bomb . in view of many by - standers he connects the bomb to the underside of a carriage . he returns to his cabin and makes a connection to a time clock . later he jumps from the train ( at high speed ) and lies in the cool grass on a river bank . looking at the stars above he decides that his job is to build and not demolish . subsequently as he sees the train approaching a giant bridging he runs at breakneck speed to board the train and stop the clock . if you care to analytical the situation it is a completely impossible task . quite ridiculous in fact . it could only happen in a dream . it ' s strange how one remembers little details such as a row of cups hanging on hooks and rattling away with the swaying of the train . despite the fact that this film is extensively acclaimed , i prefer lars von trier ' s later filmmaking ( breaking the waves and the idiots ). the bombings scene described above really put me off . perhaps i ' m a realistic .--passengers
lars von trier is never backward in trying out new techniques . some of them are very original while others are best forgotten . he depicts postwar germany as a nightmarish train journey . with so many cities lying in ruins , leo kessler a young american of german descent feels obliged to aid in their restoration . it is not a simple task as he quickly finds out . his uncle finds him a job as a night conductor on the zentropa railway line . his job is to attend to the needs of the passengers . when the footwear are polished a chalk mark is made on the soles . a terrible argument ensues when a passenger ' s shoes are not chalked despite the fact they have been polished . there are many allusions to the german fanaticism of adherence to such stupid details . the railway journey is like an allegory representing man ' s procession through life with all its trials and tribulations . in one sequence leo dashes through the back carriages to discover them filled with half - starved bodies appearing to have just escaped from auschwitz . these images , horrible as they are , are fleeting as in a dream , each with its own terrible influence yet unconnected . at a station called urmitz leo jumps from the train with a parceled bomb . in view of many by - standers he connects the bomb to the underside of a carriage . he returns to his cabin and makes a connection to a time clock . later he jumps from the train ( at high speed ) and lies in the cool grass on a river bank . looking at the stars above he decides that his job is to build and not destroy . afterwards as he sees the train approaching a giant bridge he runs at breakneck speed to board the train and ceasing the clock . if you care to analyse the situation it is a completely impossible task . pretty ridiculous in fact . it could only happen in a dream . it ' s strange how one remembers little details such as a row of cups hanging on hooks and rattling away with the swaying of the train . despite the fact that this film is widely acclaimed , i prefer lars von trier ' s later films ( breaking the waves and the idiots ). the bomb scene described above really put me off . perhaps i ' m a realist .--passengers
lars von trier is never backward in trying out new techniques . some of them are very original while others are best forgotten . he depicts postwar germany as a nightmarish train journey . with so many cities lying in ruins , leo kessler a young american of german descent feels obliged to help in their restoration . it is not a simple task as he promptly finds out . his uncle finds him a job as a night conductor on the zentropa railway line . his job is to attend to the need of the passengers . when the shoes are polished a chalk mark is made on the soles . a terrible argument ensues when a passenger ' s shoes are not chalked despite the fact they have been polished . there are many allusions to the german fanaticism of adherence to such stupid details . the railroad journey is like an allegory representing man ' s procession through life with all its trials and tribulations . in one sequence leo dashes through the back carriages to discover them filled with half - starving bodies appearing to have just escaped from auschwitz . these images , horrible as they are , are fleeting as in a dream , each with its own terrible impact yet unconnected . at a station called urmitz leo jumps from the train with a parceled bomb . in view of many by - standers he connects the bomb to the underside of a carriage . he returns to his cabin and makes a connection to a time clock . later he jumps from the train ( at high speed ) and lies in the cool grass on a river bank . looking at the stars above he decides that his job is to build and not destroy . then as he sees the train approaching a giant bridged he runs at breakneck speed to board the train and stop the clock . if you care to analyzed the situation it is a completely impossible task . pretty ridiculous in fact . it could only happen in a dream . it ' s strange how one remembers little details such as a row of cups hanging on hooks and rattling away with the swaying of the train . despite the fact that this film is widely acclaimed , i prefer lars von trier ' s later films ( breaking the waves and the idiots ). the bomb scene describing above really put me off . potentially i ' m a realist .--passengers
lars von trier is never backward in trying out new techniques . some of them are very original while others are best forgotten . he depicts postwar germany as a nightmarish train journey . with so many cities lying in ruins , leo kessler a young american of german descent feels obliged to help in their restoration . it is not a simple task as he rapid finds out . his uncle finds him a job as a night conductor on the zentropa railway line . his job is to attend to the needs of the passengers . when the shoes are polished a chalk mark is made on the soles . a terrible argument ensues when a passenger ' s shoes are not chalked despite the fact they have been polished . there are many allusions to the german fanaticism of adherence to such stupid details . the railway journey is like an allegory representing man ' s procession through life with all its trials and tribulations . in one sequence leo dashes through the back carriages to discover them filled with half - starved bodies appearing to have just escaped from auschwitz . these images , horrible as they are , are fleeting as in a dream , each with its own awful impact yet unconnected . at a station called urmitz leo jumps from the train with a parceled bomb . in view of many by - standers he connects the bomb to the underside of a carriage . he returns to his cabin and makes a connection to a time clock . later he jumps from the train ( at high speed ) and lies in the cooling grass on a river bank . looking at the stars above he decides that his job is to build and not destroy . subsequently as he sees the train approaching a giant bridge he runs at breakneck speed to board the train and halt the clock . if you care to analyzing the situation it is a completely impossible task . quite ridiculous in fact . it could only happen in a dream . it ' s strange how one remembers little details such as a row of cups hanging on hooks and rattling away with the swaying of the train . despite the fact that this film is widely acclaimed , i prefer lars von trier ' s later filmmaking ( breaking the waves and the idiots ). the bomb scene described above really put me off . perhaps i ' m a realist .--passengers

lars von trier is never backward in trying out new techniques . some of them are very original while others are best forgotten . he depicts postwar germany as a nightmarish train journey . with so multiple cities lying in ruins , leo kessler a young american of german descent feels obliged to help in their restoration . it is not a simple task as he speedy finds out . his uncle finds him a job as a night conductor on the zentropa railway line . his job is to attend to the needs of the passengers . when the shoes are polished a chalk mark is made on the soles . a terrible argument ensues when a passenger ' s shoes are not chalked notwithstanding the fact they have been polished . there are many allusions to the german fanaticism of adherence to such stupid details . the railway trip is like an allegory representing man ' s procession through life with all its trials and tribulations . in one sequence leo dashes through the back carriages to discover them filled with half - often laughs out loud funny play on sex , family , and the classes in beverly hills milks more laughs out of the zip code than it ' s seen since the days of grandmother and jed clampett . plot center on two chauffers who ' ve wagering on which one of them can bed his employer ( both single or soon to be single mesdames , quite sexy -- bisset and woronov ) first . if manuel wins , his friend will paying off his debt to a violent asian street gang -- if he loses , he must play bottom man to his friend ! lots of raunchy dialogue , fairly sick bodily humour , etc . but a lot of the comedy is just beneath the surface . bartel is memorable as a very sensual oder member of the families who ends up taking his sexy , teenaged niece on a year long " missionary trip " to africa . hilarious fun .--niece
often laughs out loud funny play on sexual , families , and the classes in beverly hills milks more laughs out of the zip code than it ' s seen since the days of grandmother and jed clampett . plot centers on two chauffers who ' ve bet on which one of them can bed his employer ( both single or soon to be single mesdames , quite sexy -- bisset and woronov ) first . if manuel wins , his friend will pay off his debt to a violent asian street gang -- if he loses , he must play bottom man to his friend ! batch of raunchy dialogue , fairly sick bodily humour , etc . but a lot of the comedy is just beneath the surfaces . bartel is memorable as a very sensual oder members of the families who ends up taking his sexy , teenage niece on a year long " missionary trip " to africa . hilarious fun .--niece
often laugh out loud funny play on sex , family , and the classes in beverly hills milks more laughs out of the zip code than it ' s seen since the days of mamie and jed clampett . plot centers on two chauffers who ' ve bet on which one of them can bed his employer ( both single or shortly to be single ladies , quite sexy -- bisset and woronov ) first . if manuel wins , his friend will paying off his debt to a violent asian street gang -- if he loses , he must play bottom man to his friends ! lots of raunchy dialogue , fairly ill bodily humour , etc . but a lot of the comedy is just beneath the surface . bartel is memorable as a very sensual oder member of the families who ends up taking his sexy , adolescents niece on a year long " missionary voyages " to africa . hilarious fun .--niece
i saw this movie in my international cinema class and was grossed out from get go . this movie is nothing but one scene of flagrant shock value after the next . the 4th man is about an alcoholic writer named reve , who has visions of his in - pending danger . he meets up with a woman named christine when giving a lecture at a local book club , and only decides to stay with her when he discovers how attractive her boyfriend is . to put it plainer , reve likes the dutch sausage . so reve concocts a plan to seduce christine ' s boyfriend so he can ultimately have sexuality with him . but its later uncovered that christine has had 3 previous husbands , who she all murdered . now reve and christine ' s boyfriend could be " the 4th man ." the storyline makes sense with no plot holes . the edit and everything else that is technical about this movie is perfectly fine . the movie is just gross and i felt the needs to vomit in some parts . predominantly , this isn ' t my cup of tea . the movie opened with reve getting out of bed in just a t - shirt . so in the very beginning , you get to see reve ' s lovely pecker flopping around as he walks around his cramped apartment in a hangover state . later on he has a dream where his pecker gets cut off by a pair of scissors , and they do show it along with the blood fountain that ensues . reve fondles a statue of jesus and has homosexual sex in a mausoleum . plus there ' s a lot of blood . more blood than all the freddie krueger movies combined . not that i have anything against " shocking " scenes , but this movie is just so overt when it comes to shocking . the whole movie is revolved around the shock value . so if any of this is your cup of tea , watch this movie . otherwise , stay far far far far far away from this one . my mind is still scarred .--jesus
i saw this movie in my international cinema class and was grossed out from get go . this movie is nothing but one scene of overt shock value after the next . the 4th man is about an alcoholic writer named reve , who has visions of his in - pending danger . he meets up with a woman named christine when giving a lecture at a local book club , and only decides to stay with her when he discovers how attractive her boyfriend is . to put it plainer , reve likes the dutch sausage . so reve concocts a plan to seduce christine ' s boyfriend so he can ultimately have sex with him . but its later discovered that christine has had 3 previous husbands , who she all slain . now reve and christine ' s boyfriend could be " the 4th man ." the storyline makes sense with no plot holes . the editing and everything else that is technical about this movie is perfectly fine . the movie is just gross and i felt the need to vomit in some parts . basically , this isn ' t my cup of tea . the movie open with reve getting out of bed in just a t - shirt . so in the very starting , you get to see reve ' s delightful pecker flopping around as he walks around his cramped flat in a hangover state . later on he has a dream where his pecker gets chopping off by a pair of scissors , and they do displaying it along with the blood fountain that ensues . reve fondles a statue of jesus and ha homosexual sex in a mausoleum . plus there ' s a lot of blood . more blood than all the freddy krueger movies combined . not that i have anything against " shocking " scenes , but this movie is just so flagrant when it comes to shocking . the whole movie is revolved around the shock value . so if any of this is your cup of tea , watch this movie . otherwise , stay far far far far far away from this one . my mind is still scarred .--jesus
this film was shrouded in scandal for so long that it became a very sought after item ... the outrage , the mystery , etc . it had everything to be a grand piece of film - making , but ultimately fails in every extent . it ' s a terribly bad comedy , a lamentable horror movie , a lame erotic film . the 2 disc dvd encompasses a gorgeous pamphlets with stills , interviews , essays on bestiality , etc . as well as an extensive interview with the more - than - pretentious director . for those who have heard circa it but never seen it , the packaging will seem wondrous until one actually sees the film . disc 1 contains the edited film , badly translated to english but with good visual quality . disc 2 contains the director ' s cut , in an awful transfer , in french . what can i say about the actual beast ? a hand puppet of kermit the frog would have been more effective and shocking .--transfer

this film was shrouded in scandal for so long that it became a very sought after item ... the outrage , the mystery , etc . it had everything to be a great piece of film - making , but ultimately fails in every extent . it ' s a terribly bad comedy , a pathetic horror movie , a lame erotic film . the 2 disc dvd includes a gorgeous leaflets with stills , interviews , essays on bestiality , etc . as well as an wide interviewing with the more - than - pretentious director . for those who have heard about it but never seen it , the package will seem wonderful until one actually sees the film . disks 1 contains the edited film , badly translated to english but with good visual quality . disc 2 contains the director ' s cut , in an grisly transference , in french . what can i say about the actual beast ? a hand puppet of kermit the frog would have been more effective and shocking .--director
what makes for best picture material ? the oskar have come in for a lot of stick for rewarding overblown spectacles that have aged poorly , and ignoring the " auteurs " who would be deified in decades to come . it wasn ' t because hollywood was against art or creativity . the academy awards are the selections made by the industry oneself , and that is why , at least in the classic era , they tended to reward the greatest collaborations , the most sensational meetings of creative minds . the arthur freed unit at mgm had been bound for oscar - winning glory for several years by this point ; it was only a matter of time before freed , aided by his strongest director vincente minnelli and some the finest musical stars in the business , would land a best photo . freed had arguably done more to raise the status of the musical than anyone else , crafting pictures which wove story and song together without losing the dynamic spectacle of the 30s musicals . the point around freed musicals , is that the lyrics of the songs , unlike those of hammerstein or lerner , don ' t have to tell or even relate to the stories . what ' s important is that the tone of the song and the way it is presented fit into the structure of the film . an american in paris was the frst of three freed musicals ( the other two being singin ' in the rain and the band wagon ) which took existing classic numbers out of their original context and made them work in a completely unrelated story . the words don ' t fit the plot , but the routines fit the show . so , when gene kelly sings i got rhythm , he hasn ' t even got a girl yet , but the way it ' s done with the french kids joining in is a great bit of characterisation , and the upbeat tune and dance gives the movie the little lift it need at this point . an american in paris also uses the rule - breaking allow in the genre to add little unconventional flights of fancy to tell the stories , such as the series of dances which accompany the description of leslie caron ' s character . and what better director for this project than minnelli , himself a painter and a pianist ? at this time there wasn ' t really anyone who had a better feel for technicolor . while some directors would saturate each scene in one colour or fill the screen with clashing shades , minnelli ' s colour plans are tightly controlled but never look forced . in the opening scenes the tones are fairly muted , but not drab , and in particular there is an absence of red . during oscar levant and georges guetary ' s meeting in the café , a few more vibrant shades are introduced . then , during the first musical number , " by strauss " minnelli gradually brings in splashes of red  a table cloth , a bunch of roses  until it eventually dominates , as if the song has awoken the picture ' s colour scheme . for most of the songs , the colours are choreographed as intricately as the people . however , in some numbers , such as " tra - la - la " he keeps the shades the same and instead opens out the space as the song swells up and the characters become more animated . the achilles ' heel of an american in paris is its story . i personally find the romantic angle particularly unpalatable , playing as it does like a last hurrah for the misogynistic love stories that reigned supreme in the 30s ; the headstrong , independent woman gets rejected while the meek , delicate girl is harassed into loving the hero . even if you don ' t mind that , it is difficult to connect emotionally with the story because it is constantly overshadowed by the songs and dances . compare this to singin ' in the rain , which doesn ' t really have as many great routines or memorable set - pieces as an american in paris , but it has a winning storyline . singin ' in the rain was overlooked at the 1952 oscars , yet it is regarded as a classic of the genre today . but i think people sometimes forget that cinema is an all - encompassing form of visual entertainment , not just a means of telling a story . an american in paris is not deep or engaging or tear - jerking but , like a certain demille picture that won the top award the following year , it certainly is a great show .--american

pieces as an american in paris , but it has a winning storyline . singin ' in the rain was overlooked at the 1952 oscars , yet it is regarded as a classic of the genre today . but i think people sometimes forget that cinema is an all -
