what makes for best picture material ? the oscars have come in for a lot of stick for rewarding overblown spectacles that have aged poorly , and ignoring the " auteurs " who would be deified in decades to come . it wasn ' t because hollywood was against art or creativity . the academy awards are the selections made by the industry itself , and that is why , at least in the classic era , they tended to reward the greatest collaborations , the most sensational meetings of creative minds . the artur freed unit at mgm had been bound for oscar - winning glory for several years by this point ; it was only a matter of time before freed , aided by his strongest director vincente minnelli and some the finest musical stars in the business , would land a best picture . freed had arguably done more to raise the status of the musical than anyone else , crafting photo which wove story and song together without losing the dynamic spectacle of the 30s musicals . the point about freed musicals , is that the lyrics of the songs , unlike those of hammerstein or lerner , don ' t have to tell or even relate to the stories . what ' s important is that the tone of the song and the way it is presented fit into the structure of the film . an american in paris was the first of three freed musicals ( the other two being singin ' in the rain and the band wagon ) which took existing classic numbers out of their original context and made them work in a completely unrelated story . the words don ' t fit the plot , but the routines fit the show . so , when gene kelly sings i got rhythm , he hasn ' t even got a girl yet , but the way it ' s done with the french kids joining in is a great bit of characterisation , and the upbeat tune and dance gives the movie the little hoist it needs at this point . an american in paris also uses the rule - breaking allowed in the genre to add little unconventional flights of fancy to tell the story , such as the series of dances which accompany the description of leslie caron ' s character . and what better director for this project than minnelli , himself a painter and a pianist ? at this time there wasn ' t really anyone who had a better feel for technicolor . while some directors would saturate each scene in one colour or fill the screen with clashing shades , minnelli ' s colour schemes are tightly controlled but never look forced . in the opening scenes the tones are fairly muted , but not drab , and in particular there is an absence of red . during oskar levant and georges guetary ' s meeting in the café , a few more vibrant shades are introduced . then , during the first musical number , " by strauss " minnelli gradually brings in splashes of red  a table cloth , a bunch of roses  until it eventually dominates , as if the song has awoken the picture ' s colour scheme . for most of the songs , the colours are choreographed as intricately as the people . however , in some numbers , such as " tra - la - la " he keeps the shades the same and instead opens out the space as the song swells up and the characters become more animated . the achilles ' heel of an american in paris is its story . i personally find the romantic angle particularly unpalatable , playing as it does like a last hurrah for the misogynistic love stories that reigned supreme in the 30s ; the headstrong , independent woman gets disallowed while the meek , delicate girl is harassed into affectionate the hero . even if you don ' t mind that , it is difficult to connect emotionally with the story because it is constantly overshadowed by the songs and dances . compare this to singin ' in the rain , which doesn ' t really have as many grand routines or memorable set - slices as an american in paris , but it has a winning storyline . singin ' in the rain was overlooked at the 1952 oscars , yet it is regarded as a classic of the genre today . but i thought people sometimes forget that cinema is an all - encompassing form of visual entertainment , not just a means of telling a story . an american in paris is not deep or engaging or tear - jerking but , like a certain demille picture that won the top award the following year , it certainly is a great displaying .--american
what makes for best picture material ? the oscars have come in for a lot of stick for rewarding overblown spectacles that have aged poorly , and ignoring the " auteurs " who would be deified in decades to come . it wasn ' t because hollywood was against art or creativity . the academy awards are the selections made by the industry itself , and that is why , at least in the classic era , they tended to reward the greatest collaborations , the most sensational meetings of creative minds . the arthur freed unit at mgm had been bound for oscar - win glory for several years by this point ; it was only a matter of time before freed , aided by his strongest director vincente minnelli and some the finest musical stars in the business , would land a best picture . freed had arguably done more to raise the status of the musical than anyone else , crafting photo which wove story and song together without losing the dynamic spectacle of the 30s musicals . the point about freed musicals , is that the lyrics of the songs , unlike those of hammerstein or lerner , don ' t have to tell or even relate to the story . what ' s important is that the tone of the song and the way it is presented fit into the structure of the film . an american in paris was the first of three freed musicals ( the other two being singin ' in the rain and the band wagon ) which took existing classic numbers out of their original context and made them work in a completely unrelated story . the words don ' t fit the plot , but the routines fit the show . so , when gene kelly sings i got rhythm , he hasn ' t even got a girl yet , but the way it ' s done with the french kids joining in is a great bit of characterisation , and the upbeat tune and dance gives the movie the little lift it need at this point . an american in paris also uses the rule - breaking allowed in the genre to add little unconventional flights of fancy to tell the story , such as the series of dances which accompany the description of leslie caron ' s character . and what better director for this project than minnelli , himself a painter and a pianist ? at this time there wasn ' t really anyone who had a better feel for technicolor . while some directors would saturate each scene in one colour or fill the screen with clashing shades , minnelli ' s colour schemes are tightly policed but never look forced . in the opening scenes the tones are fairly muted , but not drab , and in particular there is an absence of red . during oscar levant and georges guetary ' s meeting in the café , a few more vibrant shades are introduced . then , during the first musical number , " by strauss " minnelli gradually brings in splashes of red  a table cloth , a bunch of roses  until it eventually dominates , as if the song ha awoken the picture ' s colour scheme . for most of the songs , the colors are choreographed as intricately as the people . however , in some numbers , such as " tra - la - la " he keeps the shades the same and instead opens out the space as the song swells up and the characters become more animated . the achilles ' heel of an american in paris is its story . i personally find the romantic angle particularly unpalatable , playing as it does like a last hurrah for the misogynistic love stories that reigned supreme in the 30s ; the headstrong , independent woman gets repudiated while the meek , delicate girl is harassed into loving the hero . even if you don ' t mind that , it is difficult to connect emotionally with the story because it is constantly overshadowed by the songs and dances . compare this to singin ' in the rain , which doesn ' t really have as many great routines or memorable set - pieces as an american in paris , but it has a winning storyline . singin ' in the rain was overlooked at the 1952 oscars , yet it is regarded as a classic of the genre today . but i think people sometimes forget that cinema is an all - encompassing form of visual entertainment , not just a means of telling a story . an american in paris is not deep or engaging or tear - jerking but , like a certain demille photograph that wins the top award the following year , it certainly is a great show .--american
what makes for best picture material ? the oscars have come in for a lot of stick for rewarding overblown spectacles that have aged poorly , and ignoring the " auteurs " who would be deified in decades to come . it wasn ' t because hollywood was against art orr creativity . the academy awards are the selections made by the industry itself , and that is why , at least in the classic era , they tended to reward the greatest collaborations , the most sensational meetings of creative minds . the arthur freed unit at mgm had been bound for oscar - winning glory for several years by this point ; it was only a matter of time before freed , aided by his strongest director vincente minnelli and some the finest musical stars in the business , would land a best picture . freed had arguably done more to raise the status of the musical than anyone else , crafting picture which wove story and song together without losing the dynamic spectacle of the 30s musicals . the point about freed musicals , is that the lyrics of the songs , unlike those of hammerstein or lerner , don ' t have to tell or even relate to the stories . what ' s important is that the tone of the song and the way it is presented fit into the structure of the film . an american in paris was the first of three freed musicals ( the other two being singin ' in the rain and the band wagon ) which took existing classic numbers out of their original context and made them work in a completely unrelated stories . the words don ' t fit the plot , but the routines fit the show . so , when gene kelly sings i got rhythm , he hasn ' t even got a girl yet , but the way it ' s done with the french kids joining in is a great bit of characterisation , and the upbeat tune and dance gives the movie the little lift it needs at this point . an american in paris also uses the rule - breaking allowed in the genre to add little unconventional flights of fancy to tell the story , such as the series of dances which accompany the description of leslie caron ' s character . and what better director for this project than minnelli , himself a painter and a pianist ? at this time there wasn ' t really anyone who had a better feel for technicolor . while some directors would saturate each scene in one colour or fill the screen with clashing shades , minnelli ' s colour schemes are tightly controlled but never look forced . in the opening scenes the tones are fairly muted , but not drab , and in particular there is an absence of red . during oscar levant and georges guetary ' s meeting in the café , a few more vibrant shades are introduced . then , during the first musical number , " by strauss " minnelli gradually brings in splashes of red  a table cloth , a bunch of roses  until it eventually dominates , as if the song has awoken the photo ' s colour scheme . for most of the songs , the colours are choreographed as intricately as the people . however , in some numbers , such as " tra - la - la " he keeps the shades the same and instead opens out the space as the song swells up and the characters become more animated . the achilles ' heel of an american in paris is its story . i personally find the romantic angle particularly unpalatable , playing as it does like a last hurrah for the misogynistic love stories that reigned supremo in the 30s ; the headstrong , independent woman gets rejected while the meek , delicate girl is harassed into loving the hero . even if you don ' t mind that , it is difficult to connect emotionally with the story because it is constantly overshadowed by the songs and dance . compare this to singin ' in the rain , which doesn ' t really have as many great routines or memorable set - pieces as an american in paris , but it has a winning storyline . singin ' in the rain was overlooked at the 1952 oscars , yet it is regarded as a classic of the genre today . but i think people sometimes forget that cinema is an all - encompassing form of visual entertainment , not just a means of telling a stories . an american in paris is not deep or engaging or tear - jerking but , like a certain demille pictures that won the top award the following year , it certainly is a great show .--american
what makes for best picture material ? the oscars have come in for a lot of stick for rewarding overblown spectacles that have aged poorly , and ignoring the " auteurs " who would be deified in decades to come . it wasn ' t because hollywood was against art or creativity . the academy awards are the selections made by the industry itself , and that is why , at least in the classic era , they tended to reward the greatest collaborations , the most sensational meetings of creative minds . the artur freed unit at mgm had been bound for oscar - winning glory for several years by this point ; it was only a matter of time before freed , aided by his strongest director vincente minnelli and some the finest musical stars in the business , would land a best picture . freed had arguably done more to raise the status of the musical than anyone else , crafting pictures which wove story and song together without losing the dynamic spectacle of the 30s musicals . the point about releasing musicals , is that the lyrics of the songs , unlike those of hammerstein or lerner , don ' t have to tell or even relate to the stories . what ' s important is that the tone of the song and the way it is presented fit into the structure of the film . an american in paris was the first of three freed musicals ( the other two being singin ' in the rain and the band wagon ) which took existing classic numbers out of their original context and made them work in a completely unrelated stories . the words don ' t fit the plot , but the routines fit the show . so , when gene kelly sings i got rhythm , he hasn ' t even got a girl yet , but the way it ' s done with the french kids joining in is a great bit of characterisation , and the upbeat tune and dance gives the movie the little lift it needs at this point . an american in paris also uses the rule - breaking allowed in the genre to add little unconventional flights of fancy to tell the story , such as the series of dances which accompany the description of leslie caron ' s character . and what better director for this project than minnelli , himself a painter and a pianist ? at this time there wasn ' t really anyone who had a better feel for technicolor . while some directors would saturate each scene in one colour or fill the screen with clashing shades , minnelli ' s colour schemes are tightly controlled but never look forced . in the opens scenes the tones are fairly muted , but not drab , and in particular there is an absence of red . during oscar levant and georges guetary ' s meeting in the café , a few more vibrant shades are introduced . then , during the frst musical number , " by strauss " minnelli gradually brings in splashes of red  a table cloth , a bunch of roses  until it eventually dominates , as if the song has awoken the photo ' s colour scheme . for most of the songs , the colours are choreographed as intricately as the people . however , in some numbers , such as " tra - la - la " he keeps the shades the same and instead opens out the space as the song swells up and the characters become more animated . the achilles ' heel of an american in paris is its story . i personally find the romantic angle particularly unpalatable , playing as it does like a last hurrah for the misogynistic loves stories that reigned supreme in the 30s ; the headstrong , independent woman gets rejected while the meek , delicate girl is harassed into loving the hero . even if you don ' t mind that , it is difficult to connect emotionally with the tale because it is constantly overshadowed by the songs and dance . compare this to singin ' in the rain , which doesn ' t really have as many great routines or memorable set - slices as an american in paris , but it has a winning storyline . singin ' in the rain was overlooked at the 1952 oscars , yet it is regarded as a classic of the genre today . but i think people sometimes forget that cinema is an all - encompassing form of visual entertainment , not just a means of telling a stories . an american in paris is not deep or engaging or tear - jerking but , like a certain demille picture that won the top award the following year , it certainly is a great displaying .--american
what makes for best picture material ? the oscars have come in for a lot of stick for rewarding overblown spectacles that have aged poorly , and ignoring the " auteurs " who would be deified in decades to come . it wasn ' t because hollywood was against art or creativity . the academy awards are the selections made by the industry himself , and that is why , at least in the classic era , they tended to reward the greatest collaborations , the most sensational meetings of creative minds . the arthur freed unit at mgm had been bound for oscar - winning glory for several years by this point ; it was only a matter of time before liberated , aided by his strongest director vincente minnelli and some the finest musical stars in the business , would land a best picture . freed had arguably done more to raise the status of the musical than anyone else , crafting photo which wove story and song together without losing the dynamic spectacle of the 30s musicals . the point about freed musicals , is that the lyrics of the songs , unlike those of hammerstein orr lerner , don ' t have to tell or even relate to the stories . what ' s important is that the tone of the song and the way it is presented fit into the structure of the film . an american in paris was the first of three freed musicals ( the other two being singin ' in the rain and the band wagon ) which took existing classic numbers out of their original context and made them work in a completely unrelated story . the words don ' t fit the plot , but the routines fit the show . so , when gene kelly sings i got rhythm , he hasn ' t even got a girl yet , but the way it ' s done with the french kids joining in is a great bit of characterisation , and the upbeat tune and dance gives the movie the little lift it needs at this point . an american in paris also uses the rule - breaking allowed in the genre to add little unconventional flights of fancy to tell the story , such as the series of dances which accompany the description of leslie caron ' s character . and what better director for this project than minnelli , himself a painter and a pianist ? at this time there wasn ' t really anyone who had a better feel for technicolor . while some directors would saturate each scene in one colors or fill the screen with clashing shades , minnelli ' s colour schemes are tightly controlled but never look forced . in the opening scenes the tones are fairly muted , but not drab , and in particular there is an absence of red . during oscar levant and georges guetary ' s meeting in the café , a few more vibrant shades are introduced . then , during the first musical number , " by strauss " minnelli gradually brings in splashes of red  a table cloth , a bunch of roses  until it eventually dominates , as if the song has awoken the picture ' s colour scheme . for most of the songs , the colours are choreographed as intricately as the people . however , in some numbers , such as " tra - la - la " he keeps the shades the same and instead open out the space as the song swells up and the characters become more animated . the achilles ' heel of an american in paris is its story . i personally unearth the romantic angle particularly unpalatable , playing as it does like a last hurrah for the misogynistic love stories that reigned supreme in the 30s ; the headstrong , independent woman gets rejected while the meek , delicate girl is harassed into loving the hero . even if you don ' t mind that , it is difficult to connect emotionally with the story because it is consistently overshadowed by the songs and dances . compare this to singin ' in the rain , which doesn ' t really have as many great routines or memorable set - pieces as an american in paris , but it has a winning storyline . singin ' in the rain was overlooked at the 1952 oscars , yet it is regarded as a classic of the genre today . but i think people sometimes forget that cinema is an all - encompassing form of visual entertainment , not just a means of telling a story . an american in paris is not deep or engaging orr tear - jerking but , like a certain demille picture that won the top award the following year , it certainly is a grand show .--american
what makes for best photo material ? the oscars have come in for a lot of stick for rewarding overblown spectacles that have aged poorly , and ignoring the " auteurs " who would be deified in decades to come . it wasn ' t because hollywood was against art or creativity . the academy awards are the selections made by the industry itself , and that is why , at least in the classic era , they tended to reward the greatest collaborations , the most sensational meetings of creative minds . the arthur freed unit at mgm had been bound for oskar - winning glory for several years by this point ; it was only a matter of time before freed , aided by his strongest director vincente minnelli and some the finest musical stars in the business , would land a best picture . freed had arguably done more to raise the status of the musical than anyone else , crafting pictures which wove story and song together without losing the dynamic spectacle of the 30s musicals . the point about freed musicals , is that the lyrics of the songs , unlike those of hammerstein or lerner , don ' t have to tell or even relate to the stories . what ' s important is that the tone of the song and the way it is presented fit into the structure of the film . an american in paris was the first of three freed musicals ( the other two being singin ' in the rain and the band wagon ) which took existing classic numbers out of their original context and made them work in a completely unrelated stories . the words don ' t fit the plot , but the routines fit the show . so , when gene kelly sings i got rhythm , he hasn ' t even got a girl yet , but the way it ' s done with the french kids joining in is a great bit of characterisation , and the upbeat tune and dance gives the movie the little lift it needs at this point . an american in paris also uses the rule - breaking allowed in the genre to added little unconventional flights of fancy to tell the story , such as the series of dances which accompany the description of leslie caron ' s character . and what better director for this project than minnelli , himself a painter and a pianist ? at this time there wasn ' t really anyone who had a better feel for technicolor . while some directors would saturate each scene in one colour or fill the screen with clashing shades , minnelli ' s colour schemes are tightly controlled but never look forced . in the opens scenes the tones are fairly muted , but not drab , and in particular there is an absence of red . during oscars levant and georges guetary ' s meeting in the café , a few more vibrant shades are introduced . then , during the first musical number , " by strauss " minnelli gradually brings in splashes of red  a table cloth , a bunch of roses  until it eventually dominates , as if the song has awoken the picture ' s colour scheme . for most of the songs , the colours are choreographed as intricately as the people . however , in some numbers , such as " tra - la - la " he keeps the shades the same and instead opens out the space as the song swells up and the characters become more animated . the achilles ' heel of an american in paris is its story . i personally find the romantic angle particularly unpalatable , playing as it does like a last hurrah for the misogynistic love stories that reigned supremo in the 30s ; the headstrong , independent woman gets rejected while the meek , delicate girl is harassed into loving the hero . even if you don ' t mind that , it is difficult to connect emotionally with the story because it is constantly overshadowed by the songs and dances . compare this to singin ' in the rain , which doesn ' t really have as many great routines or memorable set - pieces as an american in paris , but it has a winning storyline . singin ' in the rain was overlooked at the 1952 oscar , yet it is regarded as a classic of the genre today . but i think people sometimes forget that cinema is an all - encompassing form of visual entertainment , not just a means of telling a stories . an american in paris is not deep or engaging or tear - jerking but , like a certain demille picture that won the top award the following year , it certainly is a great show .--american
what makes for best picture material ? the oscars have come in for a lot of stick for rewarding overblown spectacles that have aged poorly , and ignoring the " auteurs " who would be deified in decades to come . it wasn ' t because hollywood was against art or creativity . the academy awards are the selections made by the industry itself , and that is why , at least in the classic era , they tended to reward the greatest collaborations , the most sensational meetings of creative minds . the arthur released unit at mgm had been bound for oscar - winning glory for several years by this point ; it was exclusively a matter of time before freed , aided by his strongest director vincente minnelli and some the finest musical stars in the business , would land a best picture . freed had arguably done more to raise the status of the musical than anyone else , crafting photo which wove story and song together without losing the dynamic spectacle of the 30s musicals . the point about freed musicals , is that the lyrics of the songs , unlike those of hammerstein or lerner , don ' t have to tell or even relate to the stories . what ' s important is that the tone of the song and the way it is presented fit into the structure of the film . an american in paris was the first of three freed musicals ( the other two being singin ' in the rain and the band wagon ) which took existing classic numbers out of their original context and made them work in a completely unrelated story . the words don ' t fit the plot , but the routines fit the show . so , when gene kelly sings i got rhythm , he hasn ' t even got a girl yet , but the way it ' s done with the french kids joining in is a great bit of characterisation , and the upbeat tune and dance gives the movie the little lift it needs at this point . an american in paris also uses the rule - breaking enables in the genre to add little unconventional flights of fancy to tell the story , such as the series of dances which accompany the description of leslie caron ' s character . and what better director for this project than minnelli , himself a painter and a pianist ? at this time there wasn ' t really someone who had a better feel for technicolor . while some directors would saturate each scene in one colour or fill the screen with clashing shades , minnelli ' s colour schemes are tightly controlled but never look forced . in the opening scenes the tones are fairly muted , but not drab , and in particular there is an absence of red . during oscar levant and georges guetary ' s meeting in the café , a few more vibrant shades are introduced . then , during the first musical number , " by strauss " minnelli gradually brings in splashes of red  a tables cloth , a bunch of roses  until it eventually dominates , as if the song has awoken the picture ' s colour scheme . for most of the songs , the colours are choreographed as intricately as the people . however , in some numbers , such as " tra - la - la " he keeps the shades the same and instead opens out the space as the song swells up and the characters become more animated . the achilles ' heel of an american in paris is its tales . i personally find the romantic angle particularly unpalatable , playing as it does like a last hurrah for the misogynistic love stories that reigned supreme in the 30s ; the headstrong , independent woman gets rejected while the meek , delicate girl is harassed into loving the hero . even if you don ' t mind that , it is difficult to connect emotionally with the story because it is constantly overshadowed by the songs and dances . compared this to singin ' in the rain , which doesn ' t really have as many great routines or memorable set - pieces as an american in paris , but it has a winning storyline . singin ' in the rain was overlooked at the 1952 oscars , yet it is regarded as a classic of the genre today . but i think people sometimes forget that cinema is an all - encompassing form of visual entertainment , not just a means of telling a story . an american in paris is not deep or engaging or tear - jerking but , like a certain demille picture that won the top award the following year , it surely is a great display .--american
what makes for best picture material ? the oscars have come in for a lot of stick for rewarding overblown spectacles that have aged poorly , and ignoring the " auteurs " who would be deified in decades to come . it wasn ' t because hollywood was against art or creativity . the academy awards are the selections made by the industry itself , and that is why , at least in the classic era , they tended to reward the greatest collaborations , the most sensational meetings of creative minds . the arthur releases unit at mgm had been bound for oscar - winning glory for several years by this point ; it was only a matter of time before freed , aided by his strongest director vincente minnelli and some the finest musical stars in the business , would land a best picture . freed had arguably done more to raise the status of the musical than anyone else , crafting photo which wove story and song together without losing the dynamic spectacle of the 30s musicals . the point about freed musicals , is that the lyrics of the songs , unlike those of hammerstein or lerner , don ' t have to tell or even relate to the stories . what ' s important is that the tone of the song and the way it is presented fit into the structure of the film . an american in paris was the first of three freed musicals ( the other two being singin ' in the rain and the band wagon ) which took existing classic numbers out of their original context and made them work in a completely unrelated story . the words don ' t fit the plot , but the routines fit the show . so , when gene kelly sings i got rhythm , he hasn ' t even got a girl yet , but the way it ' s done with the french kids joining in is a great bite of characterisation , and the upbeat tune and dance gives the movie the little lift it needs at this point . an american in paris also uses the rule - breaking enables in the genre to add little unconventional flights of fancy to tell the story , such as the series of dances which accompany the description of leslie caron ' s character . and what better director for this project than minnelli , himself a painter and a pianist ? at this time there wasn ' t really anyone who had a better feel for technicolor . while some directors would saturate each scene in one colour or fill the screen with clashing shades , minnelli ' s colour schemes are tightly controlled but never look forced . in the opening scenes the tones are fairly muted , but not drab , and in particular there is an absence of red . during oscar levant and georges guetary ' s meeting in the café , a few more vibrant shades are introduced . then , during the first musical number , " by strauss " minnelli gradually brings in splashes of red  a tables cloth , a bunch of roses  until it eventually dominates , as if the song has awoken the picture ' s colour scheme . for most of the songs , the colours are choreographed as intricately as the people . however , in some numbers , such as " tra - la - la " he keeps the shades the same and instead opens out the space as the song swells up and the characters become more animated . the achilles ' heel of an american in paris is its tales . i personally find the romantic angle particularly unpalatable , playing as it does like a last hurrah for the misogynistic love stories that reigned supreme in the 30s ; the headstrong , independent woman gets rejected while the meek , delicate girl is harassed into loving the hero . even if you don ' t mind that , it is difficult to connect emotionally with the story because it is constantly overshadowed by the songs and dances . compare this to singin ' in the rain , which doesn ' t really have as many great routines or memorable set - pieces as an american in paris , but it has a winning storyline . singin ' in the rain was overlooked at the 1952 oscars , yet it is regarded as a classic of the genre today . but i think people sometimes forget that cinema is an all - encompassing form of visual entertainment , not just a means of telling a story . an american in paris is not deep or engaging or tear - jerking but , like a certain demille picture that won the top award the following year , it surely is a great show .--american
what makes for best picture material ? the oscars have come in for a lot of stick for rewarding overblown spectacles that have aged poorly , and ignoring the " auteurs " who would be deified in decades to come . it wasn ' t because hollywood was against art or creativity . the academy awards are the selections made by the industry itself , and that is why , at least in the classic era , they tended to reward the greatest collaborations , the most sensational meetings of creative minds . the arthur released unit at mgm had been bound for oscar - winning glory for several years by this point ; it was only a matter of time before freed , aided by his strongest director vincente minnelli and some the finest musical stars in the business , would land a best picture . freed had arguably done more to raise the status of the musical than anyone else , crafting photo which wove tale and song together without losing the dynamic spectacle of the 30s musicals . the point about freed musicals , is that the lyrics of the songs , unlike those of hammerstein or lerner , don ' t have to tell or even relate to the stories . what ' s momentous is that the tone of the song and the way it is presented fit into the structure of the film . an american in paris was the first of three freed musicals ( the other two being singin ' in the rain and the band wagon ) which took existing classic numbers out of their original context and made them work in a completely unrelated story . the words don ' t fit the plot , but the routines fit the show . so , when gene kelly sings i got rhythm , he hasn ' t even got a girl yet , but the way it ' s done with the french kids joining in is a great bit of characterisation , and the upbeat tune and dance gives the movie the little lift it needs at this point . an american in paris also uses the rule - breaking allowed in the genre to add little unconventional flights of fancy to tell the story , such as the series of dances which accompany the description of leslie caron ' s character . and what better director for this project than minnelli , himself a painter and a pianist ? at this time there wasn ' t really someone who had a better feel for technicolor . while some directors would saturate each scene in one colour or fill the screen with clashing shades , minnelli ' s colour schemes are closely controlled but never look forced . in the opens scenes the tones are fairly muted , but not drab , and in particular there is an absence of red . during oscar levant and georges guetary ' s meeting in the café , a few more vibrant shades are introduced . then , during the first musical number , " by strauss " minnelli gradually brings in splashes of red  a tables cloth , a bunch of roses  until it eventually dominates , as if the song has awoken the picture ' s colour scheme . for most of the songs , the colours are choreographed as intricately as the people . however , in some numbers , such as " tra - la - la " he keeps the shades the same and instead opens out the space as the song swells up and the characters become more animated . the achilles ' heel of an american in paris is its tales . i personally find the romantic angle particularly unpalatable , playing as it does like a last hurrah for the misogynistic love stories that reigned supreme in the 30s ; the headstrong , independent woman gets rejected while the meek , delicate girl is harassed into loving the hero . even if you don ' t mind that , it is difficult to connect emotionally with the story because it is constantly overshadowed by the songs and dances . compare this to singin ' in the rain , which doesn ' t really have as many great routines or memorable set - pieces as an american in paris , but it has a winning storyline . singin ' in the rain was overlooked at the 1952 oscars , yet it is regarded as a classic of the genre today . but i think people sometimes forget that cinema is an all - encompassing form of visual entertainment , not just a means of telling a story . an american in paris is not deep or engaging or tear - jerking but , like a certain demille picture that won the top award the following year , it surely is a great display .--american
what makes for best photo material ? the oscars have come in for a lot of stick for rewarding overblown spectacles that have aged poorly , and ignoring the " auteurs " who would be deified in decades to come . it wasn ' t because hollywood was against art or creativity . the academy awards are the selections made by the industry itself , and that is why , at least in the classic era , they tended to reward the greatest collaborations , the most sensational meetings of creative minds . the arthur freed unit at mgm had been bound for oscar - winning glory for several years by this point ; it was only a matter of time before freed , aided by his strongest director vincente minnelli and some the finest musical stars in the business , would land a best picture . freed had arguably done more to raise the status of the musical than anyone else , crafting pictures which wove story and song together without losing the dynamic spectacle of the 30s musicals . the point about freed musicals , is that the lyrics of the songs , unlike those of hammerstein or lerner , don ' t have to tell or even relate to the stories . what ' s important is that the tone of the song and the way it is presented fit into the structure of the film . an american in paris was the first of three freed musicals ( the other two being singin ' in the rain and the band wagon ) which took existing classic numbers out of their original context and made them work in a entirely unrelated stories . the words don ' t fit the plot , but the routines fit the show . so , when gene kelly sings i got rhythm , he hasn ' t even got a girl yet , but the manner it ' s done with the french kids joining in is a great bit of characterisation , and the upbeat tune and dance gives the movie the little lift it needs at this point . an american in paris also utilizes the rule - breaking allowed in the genre to add little unconventional flights of fancy to tell the story , such as the series of dances which accompany the description of leslie caron ' s character . and what better director for this project than minnelli , himself a painter and a pianist ? at this time there wasn ' t really anyone who had a better feel for technicolor . while some directors would saturate each scene in one colour or fill the screen with clashing shades , minnelli ' s colour schemes are tightly controlled but never look forced . in the opening scenes the tones are fairly muted , but not drab , and in particular there is an absence of red . during oscar levant and georges guetary ' s meeting in the café , a few more vibrant shades are introduced . then , during the first musical number , " by strauss " minnelli gradually brings in splashes of red  a table cloth , a bunch of roses  until it eventually dominates , as if the song has awoken the picture ' s colour scheme . for most of the songs , the colours are choreographed as intricately as the people . however , in some numbers , such as " tra - la - la " he keeps the shades the same and instead opens out the space as the song swells up and the characters become more animated . the achilles ' heel of an american in paris is its tales . i personally find the romantic angle particularly unpalatable , playing as it does like a last hurrah for the misogynistic loves stories that reigned supreme in the 30s ; the headstrong , independent woman gets refused while the meek , delicate girl is harassed into loving the hero . even if you don ' t mind that , it is difficult to connect emotionally with the story because it is constantly overshadowed by the songs and dances . compare this to singin ' in the rain , which doesn ' t really have as many great routines or memorable set - pieces as an american in paris , but it has a winning storyline . singin ' in the rain was overlooked at the 1952 oscars , yet it is regarded as a classic of the genre today . but i think people sometimes forget that cinema is an all - encompassing form of visual entertainment , not just a means of telling a tales . an american in paris is not deep or engaging or tear - jerking but , like a certain demille photographic that won the top award the following year , it certainly is a great show .--american
what makes for best picture material ? the oscars have come in for a lot of stick for rewarding exaggerated spectacles that have aged poorly , and ignoring the " auteurs " who would be deified in decades to come . it wasn ' t because hollywood was against art or creativity . the academy awards are the selections made by the industry itself , and that is why , at least in the classic era , they tended to reward the greatest collaborations , the most sensational meetings of imaginative minds . the arthur freed unit at mgm had been bound for oscar - winning glory for several yr by this point ; it was only a matter of time before freed , aided by his strongest director vincente minnelli and some the finest musical stars in the business , would land a best picture . freed had arguably done more to raise the status of the musical than anyone else , crafting pictures which wove story and song together without losing the dynamic spectacle of the 30s musicals . the point about freed musicals , is that the lyrics of the songs , unlike those of hammerstein or lerner , don ' t have to tell or even relate to the stories . what ' s important is that the tone of the song and the way it is presented fit into the structure of the film . an american in paris was the first of three freed musicals ( the other two being singin ' in the rain and the band wagon ) which took existing classic numbers out of their original context and made them work in a utterly unrelated story . the words don ' t fit the plot , but the routines fit the show . so , when gene kelly sings i got rhythm , he hasn ' t even got a girl yet , but the way it ' s done with the french kids joining in is a great bit of characterisation , and the upbeat tune and dances gives the movie the little lift it needs at this point . an american in paris also uses the rule - breaking allowed in the genre to adding little unconventional flights of fancy to tell the story , such as the series of dances which accompany the description of leslie caron ' s character . and what better director for this project than minnelli , himself a painter and a pianist ? at this time there wasn ' t really anyone who had a better feel for technicolor . while some directors would saturate each scene in one colour or fill the screen with clashing shades , minnelli ' s colour schemes are tightly controlled but never look forced . in the opening scenes the tones are fairly muted , but not drab , and in particular there is an absence of red . during oscar levant and georges guetary ' s meeting in the café , a few more vibrant shades are introduced . then , during the first musical number , " by strauss " minnelli gradually brings in splashes of red  a table cloth , a bunch of roses  until it eventually dominates , as if the song has awoken the photos ' s colour scheme . for most of the songs , the colours are choreographed as intricately as the people . however , in some numbers , such as " tra - la - la " he keeps the shades the same and instead opens out the space as the song swells up and the characters become more animated . the achilles ' heel of an american in paris is its story . i personally find the romantic angle particularly unpalatable , playing as it does like a last hurrah for the misogynistic love stories that reigned supreme in the 30s ; the headstrong , independent woman gets rejected while the meek , delicate girl is harassed into loving the hero . even if you don ' t mind that , it is difficult to connect emotionally with the story because it is consistently overshadowed by the songs and dances . compare this to singin ' in the rain , which doesn ' t really have as many great routines or memorable set - pieces as an american in paris , but it has a winning storyline . singin ' in the rain was overlooked at the 1952 oscars , yet it is regarded as a classic of the genre today . but i think people sometimes forget that cinema is an all - encompassing form of visual entertainment , not just a means of telling a story . an american in paris is not deep or engaging or tear - jerking but , like a certain demille picture that won the top awarding the following year , it certainly is a great show .--american

winning glory for several years by this point ; it was only a matter of time before releasing , aided by his strongest director vincente minnelli and some the finest musical stars in the business , would land a best picture . freed had arguably done more to raise the status of the musical than anyone else , crafting pictures which wove story and song together without losing the dynamic spectacle of the 30s musicals . the point about freed musicals , is that the lyrics of the songs , unlike those of hammerstein or lerner , don ' t have to tell or even relate to the stories . what ' s important is that the tone of the song and the way it is presented fit into the structure of the film . an american in paris was the first of three freed musicals ( the other two being singin ' in the rain and the band wagon ) which took existing classic numbers out of their original context and made them work in a entirely unrelated story . the words don ' t fit the plot , but the routines fit the show . so , when gene kelly sings i got rhythm , he hasn ' t even got a girl yet , but the way it ' s done with the french kids joining in is a great bit of characterisation , and the upbeat tune and dance gives the movie the little lift it needs at this point . an american in paris also uses the rule - breaking allow in the genre to add little unconventional flights of fancy to tell the story , such as the series of dances which accompany the description of leslie caron ' s characters . and what better director for this project than minnelli , himself a painter and a pianist ? at this time there wasn ' t really anyone who had a better feel for technicolor . while some directors would saturate each scene in one colored or fill the screen with clashing shades , minnelli ' s colour schemes are tightly controlled but never look forced . in the opening scenes the tones are fairly muted , but not drab , and in particular there is an absence of red . during oscar levant and georges guetary ' s meeting in the café , a few more vibrant shades are introduced . then , during the first musical number , " by strauss " minnelli gradually brings in splashes of red  a table cloth , a bunch of roses  until it eventually dominates , as if the song has awoken the photographic ' s colour scheme . for most of the songs , the colours are choreographed as intricately as the people . however , in some numbers , such as " tra - pieces as an american in paris , but it has a winning storyline . singin ' in the rain was overlooked at the 1952 oscars , yet it is regarded as a classic of the genre today . but i think people sometimes forget that cinema is an all - encompassing form of visual entertainment , not just a means of telling a story . an american in paris is not deep or engaging or tear - jerking but , like a certain demille picture that won the top award the following year , it certainly is a great show .--american

( understand ), monica ' s search for the " impeccable boy " ( there is no irreproachable guy , why all you women are obsessed with that ??? ), and how your marriage can be ruined when the partner of your life discovers that she ' s a lesbian . till we meet joey , phoebe and chandler in the next episodes ... enjoy friends !--friends
in the immediate aftermath following world war ii , sound minds in hollywood tried to distance themselves from the thoughtless flag - waving that is a natural ingredient in a war effort . " best years of our lives ' and even ' gentleman ' s agreement ' investigated the way americans looked at themselves in the wake of the war , but delmer daves ' " pride of the marines " defeats them to it . the film is about philadelphia shrewd alec john garfield who goes to war as a marine and after a nightmarish evening in a foxhole , with japanese soldiers eerily crying out at him and his buddies " mariiines , tonight you die ! ", he is blind by a hand - grenade , and dumps his girlfriend back habitation rather than have to depend on her after coming dwelling . delmer daves is uncompromising in his portrayal on these men who are brave , as it were , almost by coincidence . they are there , in the foxhole , and when shot at , they react . so much for heroism , but they get the job done . and afterward comes the self - pity , the dark , gloomy sense of humor . garfield is in angry denial of his blindness and the film makes no excuses , " there ' s no free candy for anyone in this world ", as his buddy tells him . the same guy , a jew , played by dane clark , recalled him , " in a war somebody gets it , and you ' re it . everybody ' s got problems ! when i get back , some guys won ' t hire me , because my name is diamond ". great movies are made with guts like these , and if the first half hour of ' pride of the marines ' fails to rises to the occasion completely , from then on it evolves into a true work of art . you weep , and you ponder , you ache and you hope against hope . well , simply : art .--brave

", he is blinded by a hand - grenade , and dumps his girlfriend back houses rather than have to depend on her after coming habitation . delmer daves is uncompromising in his depiction on these men who are brave , as it were , almost by coincidence . they are there , in the foxhole , and when shot at , they react . so much for heroism , but they get the job done . and then comes the self - pity , the dark , gloomy sense of humor . garfield is in angry denial of his blindness and the film makes no excuses , " there ' s no free candy for anyone in this world ", as his buddy tells him . the same guy , a jew , played by dane clark , reminds him , " in a war somebody gets it , and you ' re it . everybody ' s got problems ! when i get back , some blokes won ' t hire me , because my name is diamond ". great movies are made with innards like these , and if the first half hour of ' pride of the marines ' fails to rise to the occasion completely , from afterwards on it evolves into a true work of art . you weep , and you ponder , you ache and you hope against hope . well , simply : art .--brave

", he is blinded by a hand - grenade , and dumps his girlfriend back home rather than have to depend on her after coming household . delmer daves is uncompromising in his depiction on these men who are brave , as it were , almost by coincidence . they are there , in the foxhole , and when shot at , they react . so much for heroism , but they get the job done . and then comes the self - pity , the dark , gloomy sense of humor . garfield is in angry denial of his blindness and the film makes no excuses , " there ' s no free candy for anyone in this world ", as his buddy tells him . the same guy , a jew , played by dane clark , recalled him , " in a war somebody gets it , and you ' re it . everyone ' s got problems ! when i get back , some guys wins ' t hiring me , because my name is diamond ". grand filmmaking are made with guts like these , and if the first half hour of ' pride of the marines ' fails to rise to the occasion completely , from then on it evolves into a true work of art . you crying , and you ponder , you ache and you hope against hope . well , simply : art .--brave

' party of five ' gone maniacal then genetically unescapable there ' s little rooting interest because the singular non - homicidal element is a second - rate bland ghastly - acting ' wes bentley ' mopester . in fact , all of the acting is skin deep . even though the dark - haired women appealed , the salaciousness is kept to a minimum . no nudity here . also lacking are sufficient buckets of blood . all sensations are kept at a teasing , safe distancing ... an unfortunate fact considering the given name of the directors is ' butcher .' only the soundtrack , the droning angsty alt - country and the tense fluctuating score provide any perceptible tension . sometimes some static storyboarded compositions add attractive low - angles that adds to the disquiet ... but for a film that calls itself horror , i did not even get close to flinching once . perhaps a greater emphasis on societal rejuvenation through blood intake , scenes directed with varying geometric shapes outside the square , and a sustained focus on playfulness through the family ' s maliciousness or traps sympathetic characters need to escape in order to escape their quandary would have improved my opinion , but this was not a good startup to my excursion through horrorfest .--unfortunate

( contains slight spoilers ) it ' s interesting how anthony mann uses james stewart here . stuart is , of course , remembered by many as george bailey from frank capra ' s " it ' s a wonderful life ", so it ' s easy to find analogies between the two films . in " it ' s a resplendent life ", bailey gets to see the world as it would have been if he had never been born . in " the far country ", stewart ' s jeff webster , by not getting involved to helped anyone else ( except himself ), gets to see basically the same thing : a world in which he ( for all practical matters ) doesn ' t exist . by not getting participating ( and by attempting not to care about anyone ), webster is forced to see those for whom he can ' t support but care get hurt , pushed around , and even murder while he stands by and does nothing . this reminds the viewer of george bailey watching a world that ha turned upside - down because he has also decided not to get involved by not ever having been born . both movies end with the same picture - a close - up of a ringing bell . stewart , by turning around his philosophy of non - involvement , has , it would seem , earned his " wings ".--jeff
( contains slight spoilers ) it ' s interesting how anthony mann uses james stewart here . stewart is , of course , remembered by multiple as george bailey from frank capra ' s " it ' s a wonderful life ", so it ' s easy to find parallels between the two filmmaking . in " it ' s a wonderful life ", bailey gets to see the world as it would have been if he had never been born . in " the far country ", stewart ' s jeff webster , by not getting involved to help anyone else ( except himself ), gets to see essentially the same thing : a world in which he ( for all practical matters ) doesn ' t exist . by not getting involved ( and by attempting not to care about someone ), webster is compelled to see those for whose he can ' t aiding but care get hurt , pushed around , and even killed while he stands by and does nothing . this remind the viewer of george bailey watching a world that has turned upside - down because he has also decided not to get implicated by not ever having been born . both film end with the same image - a shutting - up of a ringing bell . stewart , by turning around his philosophy of non - involvement , has , it would seem , earned his " wings ".--jeff

( contains slight spoilers ) it ' s interesting how anthony mann uses james stewart here . stewart is , of course , remembered by many as george bailey from frank capra ' s " it ' s a resplendent life ", so it ' s easy to find parallels between the two films . in " it ' s a resplendent life ", bailey gets to see the world as it would have been if he had never been born . in " the far country ", stewart ' s jeff webster , by not getting involved to help somebody else ( except himself ), gets to see essentially the same thing : a world in which he ( for all practical subjects ) doesn ' t exist . by not getting embroiled ( and by attempting not to care about anyone ), webster is forced to see those for whom he can ' t help but care get hurt , pushed around , and even murder while he stands by and does nothing . this recalled the viewer of george bailey watching a world that has turned upside - down because he has also decided not to get embroiled by not ever having been born . both movies end with the same image - a close - up of a ringing bell . stewart , by turning around his philosophy of non - involvement , has , it would seem , earned his " wings ".--jeff
if you want mindless action , hot chicks and a post - apocalyptic visualise of seattle , then this is the displays for you ! the concept of dark angel isn ' t anything new ( in fact , there ' s controversy over whether james cameron stole the idea from a book ), but i spending the entire hour watching it every tuesday from start to finishes . jessica alba is smoking and max ' pals ( original cindy , kendra ) are just as hot . the fight scenes are getting better , but the dialogues between original cindy and max need to be a little bite better ( the slang sounds coerced and it sounds like someone living in the suburbs wrote it ). in my opinion , dark angel is a great guilty pleasure filled with eveything an actions fan could ask for , but if you ' re looking for hard hitting , awarding - winning drama , go watch " the west wing " or something .--fan

this movie looked as if it might be good at the beginning , but never fleshed out to it ' s expectations . the director is talented and has some good camera angles and arts thought ( typical of the asian directors ), but doesn ' t know how to create or tell a good tales to go along with it . the tales was fragmented and seemed to go off in all kinds of diverse instructions throughout the film , never finding a solid , explainable , interesting angle . basically , the movie never fit the explanation on the press releases . the acting was very good , however . all the actors gave good performances , and jude law was outstanding as he is always is . it is too bad he opt to do such a feeble film .--asian

probably the two main significances of " elmer ' s pet rabbit " are that the wacky leporid featured in " a wild hare " now has a name , and that he utters his notorious " of course you realize this means war !" for the frst time . mostly , the termite terrace crowd was still trying to figure out what exactly to do with this long - eared rascal . it ' s admittedly a gotta - see for tough - core fans of this genera , but others will probably have little reason to take interest . but make no mistake , it ' s quite hilarious what bugs bunny does to the endlessly naive elmer fudd . clear hues of things to come abound throughout the cartoon . i recommend it .--fans

sitting on the front porch of his burbank home , ted mapes told me that he and reed hadley wore the exact same size in every item of clothing except hat . ted , one of the greatest of the stunt men , said that every time zorro put on his mask , he was the one on the screen . that was a little bit of an exaggeration : there were times that zorro was obviously reed hadley , but in the stunts we can be satisfied it was ted at work . and what stunts ! " zorro ' s fighting legion " is , as witness the comments here , one of the greatest of serials . it is exciting and generally very well made . reed hadley was a fine actor , and , as someone else commented , he made a very good fop . but , admittedly , it is the action that makes this movie so great . and what else could we expect , with direction by that excellent team , witney and english , with great music from the amazingly prolific william lava ( the listing here says he was uncredited , but that is incorrect ; those other composers listed here were indeed uncredited , and i don ' t know if they did write any of the music -- it sounds like lava ), and with villainy from , among others , the great charles king , and with dozens of bit parts ? also noteworthy was a villain played by the radio tarzan , jim pierce , who was edgar rice burroughs ' son - in - law . ( i urge you to read his mini - bio .) there is one chapter that slows things down depressingly , but , heck , it ' s only a few minutes long ( maybe 20 ) and when you wade through it , well , you ' re back to the excitement . turner classic movies deserves a great big thank you for presenting this excellent serial , and we should ask tcm to bring us more . and we should thank everyone involved that we get to see it as a chapter - play , or serial , and not as a re - cut feature .--witness

" zorro ' s fighting legion " is , as witness the comments here , one of the greatest of serials . it is exciting and generally very well made . reed hadley was a fine actor , and , as someone else commented , he made a very good fop . but , assuredly , it is the action that makes this movie so great . and what else could we expect , with direction by that excellent team , witney and english , with great music from the amazingly prolific william lava ( the listing here says he was uncredited , but that is incorrect ; those other composers listed here were indeed uncredited , and i don ' t know if they did write any of the music -- it sounds like lava ), and with villainy from , among others , the great charles king , and with dozens of bit parts ? also noteworthy was a villain played by the radio tarzan , jim pierce , who was edgar rice burroughs ' son - in - law . ( i urge you to read his mini - bio .) there is one chapter that slows things down depressingly , but , heck , it ' s only a few minutes long ( maybe 20 ) and when you wade through it , well , you ' re back to the exhilaration . turner classic movies deserve a great grands thanks you for presenting this wonderful serial , and we should ask tcm to bring us more . and we should thank everyone participating that we get to see it as a chapter - play , or serials , and not as a re - cut featured .--witness
sitting on the front porch of his burbank home , ted mapes told me that he and reed hadley wore the exact same size in every item of clothing except hat . ted , one of the greatest of the stunt males , said that every time zorro put on his mask , he was the one on the screen . that was a little bit of an exaggeration : there were times that zorro was clearly reed hadley , but in the stunts we can be satisfied it was ted at work . and what stunts ! " zorro ' s fighting legion " is , as witness the comments here , one of the greatest of serials . it is fascinating and generally very well made . reed hadley was a fine actor , and , as someone else commented , he made a very good fop . but , admittedly , it is the action that makes this movie so great . and what else could we expect , with direction by that excellent team , witney and english , with great music from the amazingly prolific william lava ( the listing here says he was uncredited , but that is incorrect ; those other composers listed here were indeed uncredited , and i don ' t know if they did write any of the music -- it sounds like lava ), and with villainy from , among others , the great charles king , and with dozens of bite parts ? also noteworthy was a villain played by the radio tarzan , jim pierce , who was edgar rice burroughs ' son - in - law . ( i urge you to read his mini - bio .) there is one chapter that slows things down depressingly , but , heck , it ' s only a few minutes long ( maybe 20 ) and when you wade through it , well , you ' re back to the excitement . turner classic movies deserves a great grands thank you for presenting this wondrous serial , and we should ask tcm to bring us more . and we should gratitude everyone involved that we get to see it as a chapters - play , or serial , and not as a re - cut characteristics .--witness
for people interested in business and the corporate world , this show is simply the best of the best . as one of the former contestants of the show wrote in his blog around this innovative show : people in business finally had an audience . the whole idea is perfect ; having a group of businesspeople competing against each other in business - related tasks , set in the best place in the world , new york city . donald trump is perfect as the boss , even though his ego is bigger than the whole universe times infinity . he also makes a lot of questionable decisions about whom to fire , which is one of the negatives about the show . season 1 : great season generals , the best season of the " normal " ones . this season was the one that was most about actual business skills . later on the series almost drowned in marketing related tasks with way too many product placements . great and interesting contestants overall , with the most likable character ever in this series : troy . i know i ' m not the only person who suspect that the trump world tower - episode where he got fired was rigged to have amy and nick win this particular task . season 2 : also a great season . the tasks were still quite much ok , and it had many interesting contestants . jen m was terrible and should never had made it to the final , imo . also , this season had the worst firing ever ( pamela ). season 3 : terrible . actually , i liked the concept of book smarts vs . street smarts , but the cast was so utterly terrible ( it turned out that trump hated the cast as well ) that the whole season was a total disaster . best moments was the seconds episode ( motel renovation ), with pm brian fired , a guy who added nothing but overwhelming amounts of comedy value . season 4 : an excellent season , much because of the interesting and entertaining contestants this season ( especially randall , alla , marcus and the total disaster whose name was toral ). the " take me out to the boardroom " episode is one of the absolute classics of this exhibition , ending with the well - remembered quadruple firing . sadly , i think we got robbed for the randall vs . alla final . i think trump was afraid that she could have won , and prevented that from happening . season 5 : a boring season with really no special things to it . brent was just an embarrassment and obviously only there to create drama . the tasks were terrible overall ( how has creating a jingle anything to do with business at all ?). i guess the best man won , but personally i couldn ' t care less . season 6 : i can see why they wanted to try out l . a . as a new location for the show , but looking back it was a mistake . new york will always be the place for this . this season added so many new things , most of them terrible ( like losing team having to sleep outside in tents , winning pm continues to be pm , for example ). the tasks were terrible and trump also chose the wrong winner . james deserved it , no doubt . season 7 : celebrity edition . best season ever . totally different rules ( like the use of rolodexes ), but all fun and entertainment . the biggest problem was that many of the contestants were not real celebrities at all , especially the women where everyone were unknown to me except for omarosa , who is a total disgrace to everything she takes part in . this looked to be gene simmon ' s season , but after he made a complete fool of himself during the kodak task , another man emerged from the shadows : pier morgan . never has anyone dominated a season like he did . he crushed his opponents and also came across as a guy with a great sense of humor ( although some uptight americans ( not all americans , of course , don ' t take me wrong ) sadly didn ' t have the social proficiency to understand it ). way to go piers ! ! for fans of this i highly recommend the uk version starring sir alan sugar as the boss . in fact , the british version is manner better , and that says something since the american ( and original ) truly is a great show . one thing about the uk version is that the contestants normally tend to behave like decent human beings in the boardroom , unlike the constants yelling and rude behavior that takes place in the us version .--celebrity
with fast intercutting of scenes of crazed people in an asylum , and montage / superimposition of photo , and vague , interwoven narratives , this is a very hard movie to follow . apparently a man ( masue inoue ) takes a job as a porter orr janitor in an asylum so he can be near his imprisoned wife , and maybe to rescue her . but she ' s clearly mad , huddled on the floor , with a vacant expression much of the time and fear , misery , and confusion written on her face the rest of the time . the film - maker switches to her point of visualizing sometimes , and we see unclear images of her at the side of a pond drown a baby , or clutching at a sunk child . she ' s tormented by something . when the point of view shifts to her or other mad folks , the filmmaker usage distorting lenses and such things , showing us what mad people see and then how they react . and the place is swarming with mad folks , laughing , hiding , and in one case dancing frenetically night and day . at one point the man tries to take his wife outside , but the night outside the gate terrifies her and she runs back to her cell . gradually the man slips into a nightmare in which he ' s interrupted in another endeavour to steal her away , and he kills the doctor and many attendants , and all the while the crazed folk laugh and applaud . when he wakes he is relieved , and mops the floor . some enthralling shots of japanes life , streets , buildings in the 1920s .--porter
i happen to be the director ' s nephew . it ' s taken me years to get my hands on a copy of this film and i can confirm that it is indeed one of the lousiest movies of all time . my uncle doesn ' t even have a copy of it anymore ( i asked ). i ' m looking forward to bringing him a copied . presently the film ' s average rating is 1 . 9 / 10 . as far as i can told , that should put it someplace in the mid - 30s in the imdb " bottom 100 ," nevertheless with exclusively 206 voting , it hasn ' t yet placed . it ' s sad that the film doesn ' t even get the respect of a bottom 100 title . anyhow , i ' m giving copies of the movie to family members this year for holiday gifts . best / lousiest gift ever ?--director
paul lukas played a russian intellectual making his living as a waiter in " great slam ," directed by william dieterle ( 1933 ). it is a stunningly funny satire of the building up of celebrity . the waiter and the russian restaurant ' s hat - verification girl played by loretta young become america ' s sweethearts as bridge partners who do no squabble . with the aid of publicist and ghost - writer ' speed ' mccann ( the wonderfully deadpan frank mchugh ) they become walking advertisementsfor the " stanislavsky system ," a " system " of bidding whatever one feels like ( since bids are not rational , there is no basis for recriminations about their folly ). a duel with displaced bridge guru cedric van dorn ( sounds close to goren , no ? and i suspect the choose of the characters ' s name " stanislavsky " was also a slam at another kind of system ), a puffed - up charlatan played very well by ferdinand gottschalk , is broadcast on radio stations across america like a prize - fight by roscoe karns ( another great fast - talking deadpan comic actor of the 1930s ). the bridge players are even in a roped - off square , though the audience isabove them , unlike in boxing " rings . " the wide variety of american types prefigures the comedies of preston sturges , though for manufacturing celebrity , " grand slam " most calls to mind two better filmmaking from the same ( pre - code ) era with lee tracy playing rapids - talkingpublicists : " the half - naked truth " and " bombshell ," but " grand slam " has itsmoments , especially for anyone who has played bridge with serious pointcounters . loretta young was already a clothes horse . ( to me , her face seems a bit longand horsey , too . another era ' s notion of beauty , i guess ...) the movieunfortunately all but drops glenda farrell , who plays mchugh ' s forgetfulgirlfriend .--waiter

paul lukas played a russian intellectual making his living as a waiter in " grand slam ," directed by william dieterle ( 1933 ). it is a surprisingly funny satire of the building up of celebrity . the waiter and the russian restaurant ' s hat - check girl played by loretta young become america ' s sweethearts as bridge partners who do no squabble . with the help of publicist and ghost - writer ' speed ' mccann ( the wonderfully deadpan frank mchugh ) they become walking advertisementsfor the " stanislavsky system ," a " system " of bidding whatever one feels like ( since bids are not rational , there is no base for recriminations about their stupidity ). a duel with displaced bridged guru cedric van dorn ( sounds close to goren , no ? and i suspect the choice of the characters ' s name " stanislavsky " was also a slam at another kind of system ), a puffed - up charlatan played very well by ferdinand gottschalk , is broadcast on radio stations across america like a prize - struggle by roscoe karns ( another great quick - talking deadpan comic actor of the 1930s ). the bridge players are even in a roped - off square , though the audience isabove them , unlike in boxing " rings . " the wide variety of american types prefigures the comedies of preston sturges , though for manufacturing celebrity , " great slam " most calls to mind two better movies from the same ( pre - codes ) era with lee tracey playing fast - talkingpublicists : " the half - naked truth " and " bombshell ," but " grand slam " has itsmoments , especially for somebody who has played bridge with serious pointcounters . loretta young was already a clothes horse . ( to me , her face seems a bit longand horsey , too . another era ' s notion of beauty , i guess ...) the movieunfortunately all but drops glenda farrell , who plays mchugh ' s forgetfulgirlfriend .--waiter

mahatma has been depicted as a man who neglected his own son in this movie . don ' t get me incorrect i am not condemning the movie ; it is such a beautiful movie and walked out of the cinema with a lump in my throat . we need to fathom mahatma ' s spiritual standing , he is a genuine spiritual leader . only a fully enlightened man could possibly detach himself from his adore ones . a man with such caliber leads his families and followers by example . according to the movie , he spoke to his son and tries to make him understand where he is coming from , but poor harilall with so small intellect could not understand his father . when things went amiss with harilall , mahatma could remain calm and accepted that his son is a large tragedy . had it been any other parents , they would have jeopardised their values to assist the son to get on his feet . mahatma couldn ' t do that , he is true leader who leads by example .--leader
well , jesus of montreal is mainly an intelligent movie . the actors are indeed good and the technical side of the movie is okay . but , albeit i was very interested in the topic and like to think and discuss circa religious ( i am an atheist ), it was hard to force myself to watch the movie to the bitter and in my opinion somehow unknowingly funny end . why is this movie so immensely boring ? i don ' t know . it just is and so it is not recommendable .--jesus

first , nobody can understand why this movie is rated so poorly . not solely is this the first real horrific movie since a very long time for me who am pretty hard - boiled with a decades long experience of horror initiates with driving through dark rides ( ghost trains ) as a child . second , the main actress cheri christian has a face that lets you hope she will be the leading actress in major pictures of the future . third , this woman is that tremendously beautiful that i suggest the directors retire all those cameron diazes , eva mendezes , and how ever the names of these ephemeral bulb - lights are . mrs . christian is not a light , but a sun . however , " dark remains " is also of considerable metaphysical importance . they idea that photographic shows creatures of the intermediary reign between reality and " imagination " that are not visible with one ' own eyes is not new . but i have never seen in a movie before that those creatures are visible on the photographs only for certain people and only to certain times . this means that the pictures is not just an iconic picture of reality ( by which reality turns into a sign ), but becomes an alternative form of reality which can change as the " real " reality can . being a sign , the changing of the photo means that it influences the photographed objects , i . e . the sign behaves like an object . now , in our usual world of perception , it is common that objects change signs . f . ex ., if someone grows a bird , his photograph will show him with beard , not without , as it did before . but the opposite , the changing of objects by signs would imply that the photo with beard is first and only then the beard grows on the man . this is , very simply expressed , the case that happen with the photographs taken by the main character in the prison , in this movie . this is new , and we must be thankful for everything new in horror movies which commonly just repeat and reorder effects and traits that are already well - known , mostly since the silent time .--beard
