first , nobody can understand why this movie is rated so poorly . not only is this the first real dreadful movie since a very long time for me who am pretty hard - boiled with a decades long experiences of horror commencing with driving through dark rides ( ghost trains ) as a child . second , the main actress cheri christian has a confront that lets you hope she will be the leading actress in major pictures of the future . third , this woman is that enormously beautiful that i suggest the directors retire all those cameron diazes , eva mendezes , and how ever the names of these ephemeral bulb - lights are . mrs . christian is not a light , but a sun . however , " dark remains " is also of considerable metaphysical importance . they idea that photographs shows creatures of the intermediary reign between reality and " imagination " that are not visible with one ' own eyes is not novel . but i have never seen in a movie before that those creatures are visible on the photographs only for certain people and only to certain times . this means that the photo is not just an iconic picture of reality ( by which reality turns into a sign ), but becomes an alternative form of reality which can change as the " real " reality can . being a sign , the changing of the picture means that it influences the photographed objects , i . e . the sign behaves like an object . now , in our usual world of perception , it is common that objects change signs . f . ex ., if someone grows a bird , his photograph will show him with beard , not without , as it did before . but the opposite , the changing of objects by signs would imply that the photo with beard is first and only then the beard grows on the man . this is , very simply expressed , the instances that happen with the photographic taken by the main character in the prison , in this movie . this is new , and we must be thankful for everything new in horror movies which usually just repeat and reorder effects and characteristics that are already well - known , mostly since the silent time .--beard
my wife and i have watched this movie twice . both of us used to be in the military . furthermore being funny as hell , it affords a very realistic view of life in the navy from the perspective of a navy enlisted man , and tells it " like it really is ". we ' re adding this movie to our permanent collections !--wife

here , on imdb . com i read an opinion , that grey owl is best characters of pierce brosnan ever performed . i do not know if he had better neither worse roles , i ' m not his fan , but this one was really extraordinaire . the other thing - startling hand of the movie director . i give my respecting . the serenity , the beauty and spirit of wilderness was illustrated really exlusively , i never met such proximity it in any movie before . another thing left in my mind after the film - this is the movie , closest to the originals books , and atmosphere in it . and little bit more . i wage my respect to the original grey owl .--fan
this 1981 comedy still sparkles thanks to the combined efforts of writer / director steve gordon and stars dudley moore and john gielgud . sadly , gordon , only in his early forties , died soon after completing this , his only features film . it ' s an especially unfortunate loss since he shows a truly deft hand at character - driven farce that makes the whole film irresistible . it plays almost like a 1930 ' s - style screwball comedy revamped for contemporary tastes . the plot centers on artur bach , a drunken , diminutive millionaire playboy who is at risk of losing his $ 750 million inheritance if he doesn ' t marry the dowdy and boring susan johnson , an heiress handpicked by his old - money father and dotty grandmother . of course , he doesn ' t love her and by opportunity , runs into linda marolla , a working - class waitress ( and of course , aspiring actress ) after she pilfers a bergdorf goodman tie for her father . the standards complications ensue but in a most endearing way with loads of alcohol - fueled slapstick executed with classic élan by moore . that he makes such a spoiled character likable is a credit not only to his comic talents but to gielgud ' s feisty , acidic turn as hobson , arthur ' s devoted but reality - grounded valet . it ' s the type of role he could play in his sleep , but gielgud makes hobson such a really memorable characters that his fate in the film brings a welcome injection of poignancy in the proceedings . in probably her most likable film role , liza minnelli hands the picture to her male co - stars by toning down her usual razzle - dazzle personality and making linda quite genuine in motivation . a pre -" las law " jill eikenberry plays susan just at the right passive - aggressive note , while barney martin ( jerry ' s dad on " seinfeld ") steals all his scenes as linda ' s slovenly father ralph . the one fly in the ointment is veteran actress geraldine fitzgerald , who overdoes the eccentricities of the grandmother . and i have to admit that i still can ' t stand the very dated , overplayed christopher cross song that inevitably won the oskar for that year ' s best song . unfortunately , the 1997 dvd , certainly in need of remastering , has no extras worth noting except some photo and production note .--father
this 1981 comedy still sparkles thanks to the combined efforts of writer / director steve gordon and stars dudley moore and john gielgud . unfortunately , gordon , only in his early forties , died soon after completing this , his only features film . it ' s an particularly unfortunate loss since he exposition a truly deft hand at nature - driven farce that makes the whole film irresistible . it plays almost like a 1930 ' s - style screwball comedy revamped for contemporary tastes . the plot centers on arthur bach , a drunken , diminutive millionaire playboy who is at risk of losing his $ 750 billion inheritance if he doesn ' t marry the dowdy and boring susan johnson , an heiress handpicked by his old - money father and dotty grandmother . of course , he doesn ' t love her and by chance , runs into linda marolla , a working - class waitress ( and of course , aspiring actress ) after she pilfers a bergdorf goodman tie for her father . the standard complications ensue but in a most endearing way with loads of alcohol - fueled slapstick executed with classic élan by moore . that he makes such a spoiled character likable is a credit not only to his comic talents but to gielgud ' s feisty , acidic turn as hobson , arthur ' s devoted but reality - grounded valet . it ' s the type of role he could play in his sleep , but gielgud makes hobson such a truly memorable character that his fate in the film brings a welcome injection of poignancy in the proceedings . in probably her most likable film role , liza minnelli hands the picture to her male co - stars by toning down her usual razzle - dazzle personality and making linda quite genuine in motivation . a pre -" la law " jill eikenberry plays susan just at the right passive - aggressive noting , while barney martin ( jerry ' s dad on " seinfeld ") steals all his scenes as linda ' s slovenly father ralf . the one fly in the ointment is veteran actress geraldine fitzgerald , who overdoes the eccentricities of the grandmother . and i have to admit that i still can ' t stand the very dated , overplayed christopher cross song that inevitably won the oscar for that year ' s best song . unfortunately , the 1997 dvd , certainly in need of remastering , has no extras worth noting except some photo and production notes .--father
this 1981 comedy still sparkles gratitude to the combined efforts of writer / director steve gordon and stars dudley moore and john gielgud . sadly , gordon , solely in his early forties , died soon after finishing this , his only feature film . it ' s an especially unfortunate loss since he illustrates a truly deft hand at character - driven farce that makes the whole film irresistible . it plays almost like a 1930 ' s - style screwball comedy revamped for contemporary tastes . the plot centres on arthur bach , a drunken , diminutive millionaire playboy who is at risk of losing his $ 750 million inheritance if he doesn ' t marry the dowdy and boring susan johnson , an heiress handpicked by his ancient - money father and dotty grandmother . of course , he doesn ' t love her and by chance , runs into linda marolla , a working - class waitress ( and of course , aspiring actress ) after she pilfers a bergdorf goodman tie for her father . the standard complications ensue but in a most endearing way with loads of alcohol - fueled slapstick executed with classic élan by moore . that he makes such a spoiled character likable is a credit not only to his comic talents but to gielgud ' s feisty , acidic turn as hobson , arthur ' s devoted but reality - grounded valet . it ' s the type of role he could play in his sleeping , but gielgud makes hobson such a genuinely memorable characters that his fate in the film brings a welcome injection of poignancy in the proceedings . in probably her most likable film role , liza minnelli hands the picture to her male co - stars by toning down her usual razzle - dazzle personality and making linda quite genuine in motivation . a pre -" la law " jill eikenberry plays susan just at the right passive - aggressive note , while barney martin ( jerry ' s dad on " seinfeld ") steals all his scenes as linda ' s slovenly father ralph . the one fly in the ointment is veteran actress geraldine fitzgerald , who overdoes the eccentricities of the grandmother . and i have to admit that i still can ' t stand the very dated , overplayed christopher cross song that inevitably won the oscar for that year ' s best song . unfortunately , the 1997 dvd , certainly in need of remastering , has no extras worth noting except some photo and production notes .--father

fueled slapstick executed with classic élan by moore . that he makes such a spoiled character likeable is a credit not only to his comic talents but to gielgud ' s feisty , acidic turn as hobson , arthur ' s devoted but reality - grounded valet . it ' s the type of role he could play in his sleep , but gielgud makes hobson such a truly memorable character that his fate in the film brings a welcome injection of poignancy in the proceedings . in probably her most likable film role , liza minnelli hands the picture to her male co - this 1981 comedy still sparkles thanks to the combined efforts of writer / director steve gordon and stars dudley moore and john gielgud . sadly , gordon , only in his early forties , died soon after completing this , his only feature film . it ' s an especially unlucky loss since he shows a truly deft hand at character - driven farce that makes the whole film irresistible . it plays almost like a 1930 ' s - style screwball comedy revamped for contemporary tastes . the plot centers on arthur bach , a drunken , diminutive millionaire playboy who is at hazard of losing his $ 750 million inheritance if he doesn ' t marry the dowdy and boring susan johnson , an heiress handpicked by his old - money father and dotty grandmother . of course , he doesn ' t love her and by opportunity , runs into linda marolla , a working - class waitress ( and of course , aspiring actress ) after she pilfers a bergdorf goodman tie for her father . the standard complications ensue but in a most endearing way with loads of alcohol - fueled slapstick executed with classic élan by moore . that he makes such a spoiled character likeable is a credit not only to his comic talents but to gielgud ' s feisty , acidic turn as hobson , arthur ' s devoted but reality - grounded valet . it ' s the type of role he could play in his sleep , but gielgud makes hobson such a truly memorable character that his fate in the film brings a welcome injection of poignancy in the proceedings . in probably her most likable film role , liza minnelli hands the picture to her male co - stars by toning down her routine razzle - dazzle personality and making linda quite genuine in motivation . a pre -" la law " jill eikenberry plays susan just at the right passive - aggressive note , while barney martin ( jerry ' s dad on " seinfeld ") steals all his scenes as linda ' s slovenly father ralph . the one fly in the ointment is veteran actress geraldine fitzgerald , who overdoes the eccentricities of the grandmother . and i have to admit that i still can ' t stand the very dated , overplayed christopher cross song that inevitably won the oscar for that year ' s best song . unfortunately , the 1997 dvd , undoubtedly in need of remastering , has no extras worth note except some photo and production notes .--father

driven farce that makes the whole film irresistible . it plays almost like a 1930 ' s - style screwball comedy revamped for contemporary tastes . the plot centers on arthur bach , a drunken , diminutive millionaire playboy who is at danger of losing his $ 750 million inheritance if he doesn ' t marry the dowdy and boring susan johnson , an heiress handpicked by his old - money father and dotty grandmother . of course , he doesn ' t love her and by chance , runs into linda marolla , a working - class waitress ( and of course , aspiring actress ) after she pilfers a bergdorf goodman tie for her father . the standard complications ensue but in a most endearing way with loads of alcohol - fueled slapstick executed with classic élan by moore . that he makes such a spoiled character likeable is a credit not only to his comic talents but to gielgud ' s feisty , acidic turn as hobson , arthur ' s devoted but reality - grounded valet . it ' s the type of role he could play in his sleep , but gielgud makes hobson such a truly memorable character that his fate in the film brings a welcome injection of poignancy in the proceedings . in probably her most likable film role , liza minnelli hands the picture to her male co - this 1981 comedy still sparkles thanks to the combined efforts of writer / director steve gordon and stars dudley moore and john gielgud . sadly , gordon , only in his early forties , died soon after completing this , his only feature film . it ' s an especially unfortunate loss since he display a truly deft hand at character - driven farce that makes the whole film irresistible . it plays almost like a 1930 ' s - style screwball comedy revamped for contemporary tastes . the plot centers on arthur bach , a drunken , diminutive millionaire playboy who is at risk of losing his $ 750 million inheritance if he doesn ' t marry the dowdy and boring susan johnson , an heiress handpicked by his old - money father and dotty grandmother . of course , he doesn ' t love her and by chance , runs into linda marolla , a working - class waitress ( and of course , aspiring actress ) after she pilfers a bergdorf goodman tie for her father . the standard complications ensue but in a most endearing way with loads of alcohol - fueled slapstick implemented with classical élan by moore . that he makes such a spoiled character likable is a credits not only to his comic talents but to gielgud ' s feisty , acidic turn as hobson , arthur ' s devoted but reality - grounded valet . it ' s the type of role he could play in his sleep , but gielgud makes hobson such a truly memorable character that his fate in the film brings a welcome injection of poignancy in the proceedings . in probably her most likable film role , liza minnelli hands the photo to her male co - this 1981 comedy still sparkles thanks to the combined efforts of writer / director steve gordon and stars dudley moore and john gielgud . sadly , gordon , only in his early forties , died soon after completing this , his only feature film . it ' s an especially unfortunate loss since he display a truly deft hand at character - driven farce that makes the whole film irresistible . it plays approximately like a 1930 ' s - style screwball comedy revamped for contemporary tastes . the plot centers on arthur bach , a drunken , diminutive millionaire playboy who is at danger of losing his $ 750 million inheritance if he doesn ' t wedlock the dowdy and boring susan johnson , an heiress handpicked by his old - money father and dotty grandmother . of course , he doesn ' t love her and by chances , runs into linda marolla , a working - class waitress ( and of course , aspiring actress ) after she pilfers a bergdorf goodman tie for her father . the standard complications ensue but in a most endearing way with loads of alcohol - fueled slapstick executed with classic élan by moore . that he makes such a spoiled character likable is a credit not only to his comic talents but to gielgud ' s feisty , acidic turn as hobson , arthur ' s devoted but reality - grounded valet . it ' s the type of role he could play in his sleep , but gielgud makes hobson such a truly memorable character that his fate in the film brings a welcome injection of poignancy in the proceedings . in probably her most likable film role , liza minnelli hands the photo to her male co - stars by toning down her routine razzle - dazzle personality and making linda quite genuine in motivations . a pre -" la law " jill eikenberry plays susan just at the right passive - aggressive note , while barney martin ( jerry ' s dad on " seinfeld ") steals all his scenes as linda ' s slovenly father ralph . the one fly in the ointment is veteran actress geraldine fitzgerald , who overdoes the eccentricities of the grandmother . and i have to admit that i still can ' t stand the very dated , overplayed christopher cross song that inevitably triumphed the oscar for that year ' s best song . unfortunately , the 1997 dvd , certainly in need of remastering , has no extras worth noting except some photos and production notes .--father

this 1981 comedy still sparkles thanks to the combined efforts of writer / director steve gordon and stars dudley moore and john gielgud . sadly , gordon , only in his early forties , died soon after completing this , his only feature film . it ' s an especially unfortunate loss since he shows a truly deft hand at character - driven farce that makes the whole film irresistible . it plays approximately like a 1930 ' s - style screwball comedy revamped for contemporary tastes . the plot centers on arthur bach , a drunken , diminutive millionaire playboy who is at danger of losing his $ 750 billions inheritance if he doesn ' t wedlock the dowdy and boring susan johnson , an heiress handpicked by his old - money father and dotty grandmother . of course , he doesn ' t loves her and by chance , runs into linda marolla , a working - class waitress ( and of course , aspiring actress ) after she pilfers a bergdorf goodman tie for her father . the standard complications ensue but in a most endearing way with loads of alcohol - fueled slapstick executed with classic élan by moore . that he makes such a spoiled character likable is a credit not only to his comic talents but to gielgud ' s feisty , acidic turn as hobson , arthur ' s devoted but reality - grounded valet . it ' s the type of role he could play in his sleep , but gielgud makes hobson such a truly memorable character that his fate in the film brings a welcome injection of poignancy in the proceedings . in probably her most likable film role , liza minnelli hands the picture to her male co - stars by toning down her usual razzle - dazzle personality and making linda quite genuine in motivations . a pre -" la law " jill eikenberry plays susan just at the right passive - aggressive note , while barney martin ( jerry ' s dad on " seinfeld ") steals all his scenes as linda ' s slovenly father ralph . the one fly in the ointment is veteran actress geraldine fitzgerald , who overdoes the eccentricities of the grandmother . and i have to admit that i still can ' t stand the very dated , overplayed christopher cross song that inevitably triumphed the oscar for that year ' s best song . unfortunately , the 1997 dvds , certainly in need of remastering , has no extras worth noting except some photo and production notes .--father

this 1981 comedy still sparkles thanks to the combined efforts of writer / director steve gordon and stars dudley moore and john gielgud . alas , gordon , only in his early forties , died soon after completing this , his only feature film . it ' s an especially unfortunate loss since he display a truly deft hand at character - driven farce that makes the whole film irresistible . it plays almost like a 1930 ' s - style screwball comedy revamped for contemporary tastes . the plot centres on arthur bach , a drunken , diminutive millionaire playboy who is at risk of losing his $ 750 million inheritance if he doesn ' t marry the dowdy and boring susan johnson , an heiress handpicked by his old - cash father and dotty grandmother . of course , he doesn ' t love her and by opportunity , runs into linda marolla , a working - class waitress ( and of course , aspiring actress ) after she pilfers a bergdorf goodman tie for her father . the standard complications ensue but in a most endearing way with loads of alcohol - fueled slapstick executed with classic élan by moore . that he makes such a spoiled character likable is a credit not only to his comic talents but to gielgud ' s feisty , acidic turn as hobson , arthur ' s devoted but reality - grounded valet . it ' s the type of role he could play in his sleep , but gielgud makes hobson such a truly memorable character that his fate in the film brings a welcome injection of poignancy in the proceedings . in probably her most likable film role , liza minnelli hands the photo to her male co - stars by toning down her usual razzle - dazzle personality and making linda quite genuine in motivation . a pre -" la law " jill eikenberry plays susan just at the right passive - aggressive note , while barney martin ( jerry ' s dad on " seinfeld ") steals all his scenes as linda ' s slovenly father ralph . the one fly in the ointment is veteran actress geraldine fitzgerald , who overdoes the eccentricities of the grandmother . and i have to admit that i still can ' t stand the very dated , overplayed christopher cross song that inevitably won the oscar for that year ' s best song . sadly , the 1997 dvd , surely in need of remastering , has no extras worth noting except some photos and production notes .--father
this 1981 comedy still sparkles thanks to the combined efforts of writer / director steve gordon and stars dudley moore and john gielgud . sadly , gordon , only in his early forties , died soon after completing this , his only feature film . it ' s an especially unfortunate loss since he display a truly deft hand at character - driven farce that makes the whole film irresistible . it plays approximately like a 1930 ' s - style screwball comedy revamped for contemporary tastes . the plot centers on arthur bach , a drunken , diminutive millionaire playboy who is at danger of losing his $ 750 millions inheritance if he doesn ' t marry the dowdy and boring suzanne johnson , an heiress handpicked by his old - money father and dotty grandmother . of course , he doesn ' t love her and by opportunity , runs into linda marolla , a working - class waitress ( and of course , aspiring actress ) after she pilfers a bergdorf goodman tie for her father . the standard complications ensue but in a most endearing way with loads of alcohol - fueled slapstick executed with classic élan by moore . that he makes such a spoiled character likable is a credit not only to his comic talents but to gielgud ' s feisty , acidic turn as hobson , arthur ' s devoted but reality - grounded valet . it ' s the type of role he could play in his sleep , but gielgud makes hobson such a truly memorable character that his fate in the film brings a welcome injection of poignancy in the proceedings . in probably her most likable film role , liza minnelli hands the picture to her male co - stars by toning down her usual razzle - dazzle personality and making linda quite genuine in motivations . a pre -" la law " jill eikenberry plays susan just at the right passive - aggressive note , while barney martin ( jerry ' s dad on " seinfeld ") steals all his scenes as linda ' s slovenly father ralph . the one fly in the ointment is veteran actress geraldine fitzgerald , who overdoes the eccentricities of the grandma . and i have to admit that i still can ' t stand the very dated , overplayed christopher cross song that inevitably won the oscar for that year ' s best song . unfortunately , the 1997 dvd , admittedly in need of remastering , has no extras worth noting except some photos and production notes .--father
this 1981 comedy still sparkles thanks to the combined efforts of writer / director steve gordon and stars dudley moore and john gielgud . sadly , gordon , only in his early forties , died shortly after completing this , his only feature film . it ' s an particularly unfortunate loss since he exhibitions a truly deft hand at character - driven farce that makes the whole film irresistible . it plays almost like a 1930 ' s - style screwball comedy revamped for contemporary tastes . the plot centres on arthur bach , a drunken , diminutive millionaire playboy who is at risk of losing his $ 750 million inheritance if he doesn ' t marry the dowdy and boring susan johnson , an heiress handpicked by his old - cash father and dotty grandmother . of course , he doesn ' t loves her and by opportunity , runs into linda marolla , a working - class waitress ( and of course , aspiring actress ) after she pilfers a bergdorf goodman tie for her father . the standard complications ensue but in a most endearing way with loads of alcohol - fueled slapstick executed with classic élan by moore . that he makes such a spoiled character likable is a credit not only to his comic talents but to gielgud ' s feisty , acidic turn as hobson , arthur ' s dedicated but reality - grounded valet . it ' s the type of role he could play in his sleep , but gielgud makes hobson such a truly memorable character that his fate in the film brings a welcome injection of poignancy in the proceedings . in probably her most likable film role , liza minnelli hands the photo to her male co - stars by toning down her usual razzle - dazzle personality and making linda quite genuine in motivation . a pre -" la law " jill eikenberry plays susan just at the right passive - aggressive note , while barney martin ( jerry ' s dad on " seinfeld ") steals all his scenes as linda ' s slovenly father ralph . the one fly in the ointment is veteran actress geraldine fitzgerald , who overdoes the eccentricities of the grandmother . and i have to concede that i still can ' t stand the very dated , overplayed christopher cross song that inevitably won the oscar for that year ' s best song . unfortunately , the 1997 dvds , certainly in need of remastering , has no extras worth noting except some photos and production notes .--father

driven farce that makes the whole film irresistible . it plays almost like a 1930 ' s - style screwball comedy revamped for contemporary tastes . the plot centers on arthur bach , a drunken , diminutive millionaire playboy who is at risk of losing his $ 750 millions inheritance if he doesn ' t marry the dowdy and boring susan johnson , an heiress handpicked by his old - money father and dotty grandmother . of course , he doesn ' t loves her and by chance , runs into linda marolla , a working - class waitress ( and of course , aspiring actress ) after she pilfers a bergdorf goodman tie for her father . the standard complications ensue but in a most endearing way with loads of alcohol - fueled slapstick executed with classic élan by moore . that he makes such a spoiled character likable is a credit not only to his comical talents but to gielgud ' s feisty , acidic turn as hobson , arthur ' s devoted but reality - grounded valet . it ' s the type of role he could play in his sleep , but gielgud makes hobson such a truly memorable nature that his fate in the film brings a welcome injection of poignancy in the proceedings . in probably her most likable film role , liza minnelli hands the picture to her male co - this 1981 comedy still sparkles thanks to the combined efforts of writer / director steve gordon and stars dudley moore and john gielgud . sadly , gordon , only in his early forties , died soon after completing this , his solely feature film . it ' s an especially unlucky loss since he exhibition a truly deft hand at character - driven farce that makes the whole film irresistible . it plays almost like a 1930 ' s - style screwball comedy revamped for contemporary tastes . the plot centers on arthur bach , a drunken , diminutive millionaire playboy who is at risk of losing his $ 750 millions inheritance if he doesn ' t marry the dowdy and boring susan johnson , an heiress handpicked by his old - money father and dotty grandmother . of course , he doesn ' t love her and by luck , runs into linda marolla , a working - class barmaid ( and of course , aspiring actress ) after she pilfers a bergdorf goodman tie for her father . the standard complications ensue but in a most endearing way with loads of alcohol - fueled slapstick executed with classic élan by moore . that he makes such a spoiled character likable is a credit not only to his comic talents but to gielgud ' s feisty , acidic turn as hobson , arthur ' s dedicated but reality - grounded valet . it ' s the type of role he could play in his sleep , but gielgud makes hobson such a truly memorable characters that his fate in the film brings a welcome injection of poignancy in the proceedings . in probably her most likable film role , liza minnelli hands the picture to her male co - stars by toning down her usual razzle - dazzle personality and making linda quite genuine in motivation . a pre -" la law " jill eikenberry plays susan just at the right passive - aggressive note , while barney martin ( jerry ' s dad on " seinfeld ") steals all his scenes as linda ' s slovenly father ralph . the one fly in the ointment is veteran actress geraldine fitzgerald , who overdoes the eccentricities of the grandmother . and i have to admit that i still can ' t stand the very dated , overplayed christopher cross song that inevitably won the oscar for that year ' s best song . unfortunately , the 1997 dvd , certainly in need of remastering , has no extras worth noting except some photo and production notes .--father
